concern:
title: Thinking of applying, but I’m anxious…
Hi all, I thought this would be the best place to post this. I graduated with my BA back in 2018, & I’ve recently been toying with the idea of going to grad school. However, when I looked at my transcript recently, I was disappointed in myself when I saw my graduating GPA. It was a 2.30 I believe. I certainly was not the world’s best student, and I made a lot of mistakes. I was also working full time and dealing with loss in my personal life. I consider myself an intellectual for the most part, and seeing that GPA just made me feel a bit idiotic. The school that I was thinking of applying to told me they typically require a 2.75 but that “there are possible ways around that”. I guess what I’m wondering is do I even stand a chance at all of getting into a master’s program anywhere? Due to work & life I’d have to go the online route… I’m now 30 and much more the wiser but am just wondering if I should perhaps lose hope when it comes to the idea of grad school. Not trying to gain sympathy, just wanting some honest opinions. Thank you for your time if you read this!

dialogue.statement: Hi there! What would you like to talk about today? Feel free to share whatever is on your mind.

Hey, so I've been struggling with feeling like my course isn't really worth my time, you know? It's been affecting my motivation to do assignments, and I'm just kind of worried about how that's gonna impact my grades.

It sounds like you're feeling uncertain about the value of your course, and that's impacting your motivation and concerns about your grades. What aspects of the course make you feel it's not worth your time?

client: Honestly, it just seems like a lot of the stuff we're learning doesn't really apply to anything practical. It feels like I'm just doing work for the sake of it without any real-world application.
You feel frustrated because the course material doesn't seem to connect with practical, real-world applications. What impact does that have on your overall experience with the course?
It's been making it hard to stay motivated and actually care about doing well. I just feel kind of checked out, like I'm going through the motions without really engaging with the content.

statement.reasoning: The conversation has effectively elicited the client's thoughts, feelings, and context regarding their course and motivation issues. The client has expressed specific concerns and impacts on their academic performance. The therapist has shown empathy and understanding, and the goals have been mutually agreed upon. It's appropriate to transition to strengthening motivation and evoking Change Talk.

dialogue.statement: It sounds like you're feeling disengaged, which is affecting your motivation and connection to the course. How might things look different if you felt the course was more relevant to your life goals?

If the course felt more relevant, I think I'd be more motivated to put in the effort and actually learn. It'd probably make me feel like what I'm doing has a purpose, and not just jumping through hoops for grades.

Connecting what you're learning to your life goals could indeed bring a sense of purpose and motivation. What are some of your long-term goals, and how might this course eventually align with them, if at all?

I guess one of my long-term goals is to work in a field where communication is key, maybe something like public relations or media. If the course could somehow tie into understanding language in those contexts, it might feel more relevant.

Exploring how this course ties into communication skills in fields like public relations or media could definitely make it more meaningful for you. What aspects of the course, if any, do you feel could currently support these goals?

client(guiding): Well, I suppose some of the language analysis parts could be useful in understanding how to craft messages effectively or analyze media content. But it's hard to see the connection sometimes when it's buried in theory.

statement.reasoning: The client has shown Change Talk by recognizing the value of course material related to long-term goals. They are contemplating putting effort into assignments again and have expressed a desire to improve. Discrepancy between current behavior and values has been explored, and potential relevance to goals has been discussed. A specific change goal has emerged: to put effort into assignments. The client’s motivation appears to be strengthening, signaling readiness to develop action plans.

dialogue.statement: Therapist(choosing): Let's explore ways to make these language analysis parts feel more applicable to your goals. One option might be to focus assignments on real-world communication examples, like media content or public relations campaigns. How does that sound to you?
client(choosing): That actually sounds pretty cool. If I can tie in some real-world stuff into what I'm learning, it might make a lot more sense and feel less like just theory.

We can work on an action plan to incorporate real-world examples into your assignments. You could start by selecting media content or campaigns that interest you and analyze them using course concepts. Another option might be finding a study group interested in similar goals for collaborative learning. What do you think about these possibilities?

Those ideas sound really promising! Analyzing media content or campaigns could definitely make things more engaging. I'm also open to joining a study group to share insights and learn collaboratively, it might help with feeling less isolated in this.

It's great to hear you're open to these ideas. Let's set a goal to start integrating real-world examples into your studies. You could choose one media piece or campaign to analyze each week. For the study group, you might reach out to classmates or online forums to find others with similar interests. What steps do you feel ready to take first, and how can I support you in moving forward?

client(choosing): I think I'll start by picking a media piece or campaign to analyze this week. I’ll also post on our class forum to see if anyone's interested in forming a study group. It would be helpful if we could check in next session to see how it's going and keep me accountable.

statement.reasoning: The client has identified a clear goal and a concrete action plan involving real-world analysis and forming a study group. Barriers such as isolation and relevance have been addressed, and self-monitoring through check-ins is established. The client demonstrates commitment by specifying first steps and is open to support. There are readiness signals including taking-steps talk and confidence in the plan, indicating progress beyond the Choosing phase.

dialogue.statement: That's a fantastic start! Choosing a media piece to analyze and reaching out on the class forum are both proactive steps. I'm here to support you, so let's plan to review your progress together in our next session. Remember, this journey is about finding what makes learning meaningful for you. Keep exploring and engaging with content that resonates with your goals. You’ve got this, and I’m here to cheer you on every step of the way. Looking forward to hearing about your experiences next time.
Thanks! I appreciate your support in this. I'll get started and see how things go. Looking forward to checking in with you next session.

statement.reasoning: The client has a clear next-step plan, including analyzing media content and forming a study group. The session naturally concluded with a plan to check progress in the next meeting.

concern:
title: Submitting a barely started assignment
Soo , I’m in second year of university studying English Language and Linguistics .. since I started second year I’ve been thinking that my course is just so useless and have had no motivation to do the work so I have just been starting them the day before and submitting barely finished work. For my first one I got 58% (for one module) then I got 68% (for another module) .. I still have one more assignment for each module (so two left)

However for another module I had two assignments literally wrote like 500 words out of 2000 for each and just submitted it … I’ll probably get like 20% on them both .. I’ve realised after this, I might as well just start putting in effort again .. if I do well in my other courses , do you guys think I will be able to retake the module that I failed?

Thanks

dialogue.statement: Hello! What would you like to talk about today? Feel free to share what's on your mind.
Hey, I've just been feeling pretty anxious about my living situation for this upcoming school year. I'm worried about how well I'll get along with my roommates.
It must be challenging to have those concerns about your living situation and roommates. What are some of the specific things that are making you feel anxious about it?

client(exploring): Well, it's mostly about not knowing what to expect and if our personalities will clash. I've had bad experiences with similar personalities in the past, and I'm worried it might happen again.

It's understandable to feel anxious when faced with uncertainty and past experiences. You're worried about potential personality clashes with your roommates because of what you've gone through before. Could you tell me more about those past experiences and how they affected you?

client(exploring): Yeah, I guess it's mostly from high school. I often felt like I was on the outside looking in, and the more outgoing, popular kids weren't always the nicest. It just left me a bit wary of those types.

statement.reasoning: The client has shared their primary concern, past experiences, and feelings about the current situation, allowing for an understanding of the context and emotional impact. Rapport has been established, and the mutual goal of addressing anxiety about the living situation is clear. The conversation has reached a point where it could benefit from guiding towards exploring motivations and potential solutions.

dialogue.statement: It sounds like those high school experiences left a lasting impact, making you cautious about similar personalities now. Considering your upcoming living situation, what would it be like if things went well and you got along with your roommates?
I guess it would be a huge relief. If we got along, it could make my first year away from home so much more enjoyable and maybe even help me feel more comfortable and confident.

dialogue.statement: Connecting with your future roommates beforehand sounds like a solid way to ease some of your anxiety. Starting a group chat might lead to those positive interactions you're hoping for. How would you feel about taking that step and reaching out to them?

client(guiding): I think it could be a good idea. It might feel a little awkward at first, but if it helps me feel more comfortable, it'd be worth a try. Plus, it'll give me a better sense of what they're like.

dialogue.statement: Taking that step to reach out could be really beneficial in getting a sense of their personalities and establishing some comfort before moving in. What values or qualities are important to you in forming these new connections?

While there is an identified next step, the confidence level is not yet high enough, and the client continues to express significant anxiety about potential outcomes. Thus, it would be beneficial to continue guiding to further explore these feelings and increase confidence.

dialogue.statement: Honesty and respect are indeed fundamental for any healthy relationship. Emphasizing these values could set a strong foundation for mutual understanding with your roommates. How do you think these qualities could influence your experience living together if everyone prioritizes them?

client(reflecting): If everyone values honesty and respect, it could make things a lot smoother. We could address issues directly without letting things fester, and it'd be easier to feel comfortable and at home in the space if we all respect each other's boundaries.

statement.reasoning: The client has expressed a specific change goal of starting a group chat with roommates to ease anxiety. The confidence level is currently at 5, indicating openness to change but still some uncertainty. concern:
title: Should I try to request a room change?
So, I’m moving out in 10 days. I’m staying at an off campus apartment because all the dorms at my college are on a waitlist. I got randomly paired with 3 girls, 1 I talked to before and 2 more that I didn’t. I’m not so concerned about the one I touched base with before as I am about the 2 others. This one girl especially just doesn’t seem like the kind of person I’d get along with at all - I know I shouldn’t be making assumptions but based off what she told me and looking at her instagram she seems like an extroverted popular party girl type. Not to trauma dump but most of the people who bullied me in the past have been those kinds of people. The other one I still am unsure about but I literally know nothing about her, she might very well be the same kind of person. I really don’t know if I’m going to be comfortable in this kind of situation. I know it’s kind of unfair for me to judge these people without having even met them but I have a bad gut feeling and I’m really anxious. I don’t want my first year away from home to be a living hell because I’m not able to get along with these people. I know I could try to set boundaries but who’s to say they’ll listen? 

Anyways, Im thinking about calling the rental office and asking for a room change but I’m unsure. I don’t know if it’s worth it because what if I end up in an even worse situation or I somehow lose my placement? I really want to go with my gut here but I just don’t know. Plus it may be difficult with this being a private housing complex and not a dorm.

dialogue.statement: Hello! What brings you here today? Feel free to share anything that's on your mind.

Hey, I've just been thinking a lot about going back to school to become a physio. I'm just not sure if it's the right move, especially since I'm starting a bit later and the idea of student debt is really stressing me out.

You're contemplating returning to school for physiotherapy, but starting later and the potential student debt feel overwhelming. What's drawing you to this potential career path, and how do you feel about these concerns?
I think the idea of helping people recover and improve their lives is super rewarding. But then, I'm also worried about the long time commitment and the financial burden it'll put on me.

The thought of aiding others in their recovery sounds deeply fulfilling to you, yet the commitment of time and finances is weighing heavily on your mind. What do you feel is most important to consider as you weigh these options?
client(exploring): I guess it's about balancing passion with practicality. I want to make sure I'm making a decision that's not just emotionally driven but also makes sense for my future stability.

statement.reasoning: The client has shared their thoughts on pursuing physiotherapy, the rewarding aspect of helping others, and concerns about student debt and time commitment. They've also talked about balancing passion with practicality. The essence of their story and feelings have been explored, and rapport seems established.

dialogue.statement: Balancing passion with practicality is a thoughtful approach. How do you envision your life if you choose to pursue this path, and how might it differ if you decide not to?

If I go for it, I imagine doing something I love, but possibly being weighed down by debt for a long time. If I don't, I might settle for a job that's less fulfilling, but at least I'd be more financially stable. It's tough to see which outweighs the other right now.
Choosing between following your passion and ensuring financial stability seems like a complex decision. What aspects of your future life feel most aligned with your core values and long-term goals?

client(guiding): I really value making a positive impact and feeling accomplished in my work. But I also want stability, where I don't have to stress about money all the time. Trying to figure out which of those is more important to me is the hard part.

Making a positive impact and feeling accomplished in your work, while also wanting financial stability, are both important to you. On a scale from 0 to 10, how confident do you feel about finding a path that honors both of these values?
client(reflecting): I think I'm around a 5 right now. It feels like a toss-up because I can see potential for both, but I'm not quite sure how to get there.

statement.reasoning: The client has expressed both Change Talk and Sustain Talk, showing ambivalence. While they have explored their values and future with and without the change, their confidence remains low (5), indicating uncertainty. No specific change goal or next step has been identified. Thus, further guidance is needed to strengthen motivation and clarify goals.

dialogue.statement: Being at a 5 shows that you're open to finding a balance, which is a great start. What might help you feel more confident about moving towards a decision that respects both your desire for impact and financial stability?

client(reflecting): Maybe talking to people who've been through it or getting advice from someone in the field could help. I think hearing real experiences about balancing the debt and the work satisfaction might give me a better perspective.

statement.reasoning: The client has expressed Change Talk and identified a potential next step by considering talking to others for advice. However, their confidence is at 5, indicating ambivalence remains. They need further exploration of specific goals and support strategies before advancing to Choosing.

statement.reasoning: The client is still expressing ambivalence (conflict between passion and financial stability) and reports confidence at a 5 out of 10. While they've identified useful steps like talking to others in the field and a financial advisor, there's no specific change goal or increased confidence. The guiding phase should continue to further explore ambivalence and strengthen confidence.

dialogue.statement: Exploring different sources like career fairs and seeking advice from a financial advisor sounds like a proactive approach to gather more insights. As you look into these options, how do you imagine they might influence your confidence in making a decision that aligns with your values and goals?

client(reflecting): I think they could definitely help clarify things, maybe tipping the scale one way or the other. Just having concrete information and advice could make me feel more secure in whichever choice I lean towards.

statement.reasoning: The client has expressed Change Talk by considering actions such as talking to people, researching, and consulting a financial advisor. Having a dedicated time each week and using a planner or an app to stay organized are excellent strategies for managing your time effectively. concern:

dialogue.statement: Hello! It seems like you might have something on your mind. Whenever you're ready, feel free to share what's been going on lately.
Hey, yeah... I'm just really confused about whether to stick with computer science or switch to business. Everything feels overwhelming, and I'm not sure what the right move is.

It can be really tough when you're caught between two big decisions. You seem to feel overwhelmed because both paths have their own appeal and challenges. What's been influencing your thoughts about each option?

Well, with computer science, it's more about the potential for a secure future, but it's tough for me to grasp it. Business seems more manageable, but I've heard it might not be as beneficial career-wise, which makes me second-guess switching.

Balancing future security with manageability can definitely create a whirlwind of thoughts. You seem to feel torn because computer science offers stability, yet it feels challenging, while business feels within reach but raises concerns about long-term benefits. What aspects of each field excite or concern you the most?

client(exploring): For computer science, I like the idea of working with technology and the opportunities it brings, but the complex concepts really intimidate me. With business, I’m interested in entrepreneurship and the creativity involved, but I worry about the job market and if it’s worth the investment.

client(guiding): Honestly, with computer science, I see stability and growth, but I'm worried I'll struggle too much to enjoy it. Business aligns more with creativity and enjoyment, but I’m not sure if it’ll offer the stability I want in the long run.

Both options appear to hold unique parts of what you value in a career. As you think about the possibility of struggling with certain aspects of computer science, how does this fit with your vision of enjoying and growing in your work?

client(guiding): That's a big concern for me. If I'm constantly struggling, I'm worried it might overshadow any enjoyment or growth I could have in the field. I want to feel confident and fulfilled in my work, not always stressed and overwhelmed.

statement.reasoning: The client has expressed concerns and values but is still unsure about long-term goals, showing ambivalence. The discrepancy between values and concerns has been explored, yet specific change goals or next steps are not clearly defined. Confidence in decision-making is still lacking, indicating a need for further guiding before moving to the choosing phase.

dialogue.statement: Your desire to feel confident and fulfilled in your career speaks volumes about what you value in your work life. How might the potential for stress and struggle in computer science influence your confidence and fulfillment compared to the creative aspects of business?

client(guiding): I think the stress and struggle in computer science could really hit my confidence hard. It feels like there's always a massive learning curve ahead. concern:
title: Stay in computer science or switch to business?
I’d appreciate any sort of help as I’m lost. I’m currently in Turkey on vacation with my parents but I need to decide what I want to do so I can make it to the fall term. 

I started my computer science major online in 2020 in a university for one year, than switched to a different university for applied computer science for another year first semester online, second in person. I’m going into my third year after the summer and I barely have any knowledge of the subject I’m doing. I’ve had a difficult time learning online and learning computer science in general. 

I did some thinking and the only reason I want to switch is because I find computer science hard, which I don’t think is a valid reason for me, and it’s only going to get harder as I’m closing in on the major. I can’t decide if I want to switch to business or not. People say that business is useless and a waste of money, while computer science is the future and has well paying jobs. 

I’m so lost at what I’m supposed to be doing and it’s so stressful. I’d kindly appreciate any kind of input.

dialogue.statement: Hello! It seems like you might have something on your mind. What would you like to talk about today?
Hey, yeah, I've got a lot going on. I'm thinking about leaving school because my mental health is struggling, and it's really overwhelming.

That sounds incredibly challenging. You're feeling overwhelmed because managing school alongside your mental health is becoming too much to handle. Could you share more about what's been particularly difficult for you lately?
I just feel like I can't keep up with everything, and it's making me really anxious. It's been hard to focus on my studies when I'm constantly worried about how I'm feeling.

It seems like the constant worry about your well-being is making it difficult to concentrate on your studies. This must be quite stressful for you. What specific parts of school are adding to your anxiety and making things feel unmanageable?
Honestly, it's just the pressure to keep up with assignments and the fear of failing. I also feel out of place and like I'm not really cut out for this right now.

statement.reasoning: The client has expressed their thoughts and feelings regarding their mental health, school, and potential plans, providing detailed context. Empathy and rapport seem established, and the client's goals and options are mutually understood. The client has a clear plan in mind and seeks support. These factors suggest readiness to shift focus toward strengthening motivation and evoking Change Talk.

dialogue.statement: It sounds tough to feel such pressure and uncertainty about your place in school. When you think about staying in school versus leaving, what are the thoughts or feelings that stand out for you?
client(guiding): When I think about staying, I just feel trapped and stressed. But the idea of leaving makes me feel guilty, like I'm letting people down. It's like a tug-of-war in my head.

Balancing those intense emotions must be exhausting. On one hand, staying feels suffocating, while on the other, leaving brings guilt. What do you imagine your life could look like if you chose to stay or if you decided to leave?

If I stay, I worry I might just keep spiraling and not actually get better. If I leave, I imagine feeling some relief, maybe a bit of peace, and having time to work on myself. But there's that fear of disappointing everyone.

It seems like you're torn between the possibility of finding peace and the fear of disappointment. Taking a step back and imagining life either way can be insightful. What aspects of your life hold the most importance to you right now, and how do these values align with your thoughts on staying or leaving?

client(guiding): Right now, I think my mental health and well-being are the most important to me. I want to be able to take care of myself and actually enjoy what I'm doing. I guess leaving aligns more with that, even though it's hard to face the potential disappointment from others.

statement.reasoning: The client has demonstrated a clear understanding of their priorities and values, with a focus on mental health and well-being. They have expressed specific change goals, such as leaving school and working to improve their mental health. Change talk is present, and ambivalence has decreased, as evidenced by their recent decision to withdraw and make plans for the future.

client(choosing): I think I can reach out on my own, but it might be nice to have a friend or family member with me for a little encouragement. Just someone to remind me that I'm doing the right thing and to help keep me on track.

concern:
title: Will I be a failure for dropping out and working a minimum wage job?
My mental health has been really bad. I’m able to get a refund on tuition if I drop now. I’ve only been here three days (I’m in my second year) and I already am having mental breakdowns. My other option is to work at a retirement home, which honestly I don’t mind. I feel like it would relieve a load of pressure and stress off of me. 

But I know I’d disappoint everyone in my life but honestly I’m used to that. Idk. I haven’t talked with my professors or anything. Idk anymore. I get so upset I feel sick. I really feel I’d be happier just going to a better school later while building my skills through some online stuff and books in my spare time (I’m in a tech program) and saving up for a course better suited for me when I’m ready and can take care of my health.

Idk :(

Edit : thank you all for the advice. 
I’ve made my plans. I’ve requested withdrawal forms. I talked to my mom and grandmother and they supported my decision, so I can live with them with low rent now. I plan to work and pay off my loans (they weren’t very much) the first year and then I plan to work for another year or two and save up for a school better suited for a program that I would be happier pursuing. I hope to seek mental health help too so I can function and gain life experience before going back. Thank you guys again. I read all replies and appreciate them all.

concern:
title: Anyone else struggle with lab techniques?
Hey, Neuroscience Ph.D. candidate here. I work in a systems neuroscience lab. Therefore, one of the things you probably guess that we do are surgeries, except I could never learn how to do them. In short, the post-doc who taught me was not a very good teacher and the lab environment has not been the best for learning. I was taking so long to learn them that my PI basically said that the staff research scientist would do all my surgeries while I focused on building other skills. This has been probably one of the single biggest blows to my confidence as a researcher. A skill that I was sure I could learn. Everyone else in my cohort was able to learn them but me, and I cannot get over this. I hate being the only one who seems to not be able to do a very core thing in systems neuroscience. 

Any advice is welcome. I am trying my best to look past this, but it's hard. I am not particularly good at anything else. So, I am not bringing some other core skill to the lab that makes up for this deficiency.

dialogue.statement: Hi there! What brings you in today? Feel free to share what's on your mind.

Yeah, it's been pretty draining. I find myself spending extra time second-guessing my assignments and worrying if I'm missing something important. It's like I'm constantly on edge, trying to figure out what they really want.

client(reflecting): I usually just try to power through by overanalyzing everything, like rereading instructions a million times or checking with classmates to see if they’re as confused as I am. Sometimes I’ll vent to friends, but it doesn’t always help the stress go away.

statement.reasoning: The client has shared their concerns about unclear communication from professors and how it impacts their stress and coping mechanisms. concern:
title: Professor's instructions often unclear? What's the deal?
I keep running into this issue where instructors will often give vague instructions on assignments and I'm not sure what to do about it. Do I just need to get better at navigating vague teachers? Or is this not supposed to be happening?

___

**Exhibit A:**

For example, I just got my grade back for a programming project in which I was apparently not allowed to edit certain parts of the code that was provided. I got docked quite a few points for this mistake so I double checked the grading rubric and there is no mention of any restrictions on editing the prewritten code. I scroll down to the very bottom and of course, hidden in the middle of an FAQ section, is the warning to not edit prewritten code. Yes, I should probably be reading every single word of every piece of instruction just in case, but isn't the FAQ generally optional reading? Why is there crucial grading criteria in an FAQ section and but nowhere to be found in the actual "Grading Criteria" section?

___

**Exhibit B:**

Another professor, this same quarter, docked me for not formatting the output of a program in exactly the right way. The rubric does mention that "the output must be in the required format" but it didn't specify what the format is. While I was working on this assignment, I read through the whole rubric a couple of times and couldn't find any other mention of a "required format". When I turned it in, I added a note on canvas that basically read: "I wasn't sure what you meant by required format. Please let me know if there are any issues. I can send you the source code if you need to look at it for grading purposes".

She graded the assignment with a very dismissive response saying simply "Numerical output was not in the required format". I had to ask her again about this "required format" and she  responds with "There was a sample line of code provided in the PDF file". I look back at the instruction PDF and there is an example piece of code much later in the assignment that states "you ***may*** use fprintf() to output a ***desired*** format" but the wording does not suggest in any way that this ***is*** the ***required*** format above. The wording makes it seem like a completely unrelated suggestion or helpful tip rather than a strict requirement, especially since it appears many paragraphs after any mention of a ***required*** format.

___

Am I losing it? If this is happening in multiple classes in the same quarter then it must be me right? But I feel like there are *definitely* some huge communication issues going on. I'm not really sure what to think. Hopefully this post doesn't come off too ranty. I'm just not sure what to do. Why does this keep happening? Is interpreting vague instruction just a skill I need to develop? Or should I be talking to my teachers about this?

concern:
title: Physics, Biology: Dilemma on whether I should switch my major ft. mental health
TLDR is at the bottom as well as my questions. This turned out very long, I apologize.

To start out i would like to say this: I love physics, ever since i was in elementary school i've loved physics phenomena, lasers, optics and had marvelled at the fact that we can explain so much about the universe. I took physics as one of my Leistungskurse (elevated courses with more hours in German high schools), did my hs graduation exam in it and finished with an excellent score. I really did enjoy it all the way and our teacher was super chill and supportive, in general all my physics teachers were very cool and made our lessons fun with many very interesting experiments. It's a language that we can explore the universe in and that makes it very exciting.

So it's no wonder i went into university pretty determined on physics, however i didn't make my decision based on one specific job i wanted to do, but coming from a thirst for knowledge.

In high school, my strategy was to pay attention in lessons and thoroughly write everything down and take notes. I wasn't the kid that caught up to everything the teacher said in the lesson and when preparing for exams or revising I would sit and go through everything by myself. This was a very good method for me personally because i could understand the concepts and their connections in my own pace and understand things through my own methods. It might sound weird that the kid who was regarded as one of the top students sometimes couldn't have answered the most simple questions on a new topic, but that's how it was, i just needed the time.

But ever since the bridge courses before the semester i've been struggling. I'm told that it's normal for first years to feel like everyone around you knows everything and only you are behind, but after a semester the feeling is still strongly there. I will admit I have made many mistakes, like starting the more in-depth math courses from the beginning and not revising after every other class. As the workload was immense, I barely slept in the first two months. This in turn lead to me barely being able to stay awake in class and tutorials. I acknowledge these mistakes and have already made adjustments to lighten the load.

Now, as for uni, the sheer amount of stuff we have to learn, on our own, at my university -which might be a normal amount, given this is university- is a lot to approach with my method. We were advised to study in groups and do our weekly exercise sheets together, and though I had some moments of victory where I could do one exercise, mostly it consisted of the other students talking about the topic like they understood it really well while I sat there and listened for any coherent crumbs of info and sometimes asked for a tip on how to proceed. Admittedly this was not a good method and I found some people closer to my pace who I could study with, but they weren't always there or we ended up sitting with our sheets well into dusk. So by the time I got home I was tired and turned to my phone for an escape lot of the time. Now I know that delaying catching up with our topics is a bad strategy due to time and the amount of material. But it seems like it's good if i take the time to catch up and revise by myself, also because the way things are explained in class don't always work for me.

As for the social aspect of it, there wasn't really a time where I felt that I fit in or that I have much in common with anyone there except maybe when we were talking about art. I also found myself rethinking my choices a lot. I missed my friends and my family immensely and honestly struggled to feel human at times. I haven't really been able to find the motivation to study beyond the desire to get through another week.

When I look into what kind of scripts belong to classes in later semesters, the topics seem interesting, still it's pages of text with about the same amount of equations which i'm sure contain so much interesting and informative stuff.. Still right now that aspect of "woah that's so cool" is kind of missing. Maybe that will come later, i figure when we get to more stuff that's beyond mechanics.

I suspect I might also have ADHD and may be nd in other ways which i will get checked out with a professional if i am able to. So to be clear i'm not self diagnosing, but i'm constantly reading up on these subjects and honestly everything seems to make so much more sense.

So that's a little bit on how I have felt about my first semester of physics.

The thing is, beside physics, I'm also very interested in biology. Our university has a small biology faculty and it seems to be much cozier than 200-300 people in physics. The longer i've thought about it, the more i find myself interested in life and the parts of science that deal with living things. I took biology as a Basiskurs (a course that has less lessons and is more simplified compared to Leistungskurs) and I loved it. At school i've done several presentations in both physics and biology (and ethics) and I loved doing those, I find it's so much fun to research things and share them with others in a way that's engaging and comprehensive. I watch science videos and listen to podcasts in my free time as well, like Scishow (both vids and podcasts) and books like The Selfish Gene (that i found super interesting and recommend!!), and generally beside physics, a lot of them have a lot to do with biology. I find that these pieces of media don't overwhelm me and i want to know more about them, in general all kinds of stuff that have to do with life feel like tangible things to me and they kind of fall into place in the big scheme of things. I hope i phrased that in a way that's understandable.

I will implement new strategies in the coming semester and am in the process of hopefully getting a private tutor. I'm determined to go through my second semester in physics and reevaluate things after, but the way things are looking for me mentally right now, i think going with something that is naturally and directly engaging and has a sense of novelty and many little rewards that are directly applicable (so: biology) would lighten the load for now. Going into uni i talked with some advisors from both faculties on doing two bachelors, they said it was possible but i should rather wait. I would even consider doing them one after another with no overlap (of course i'd have to start working a job too eventually, to afford rent and basic expenses, right now i have a very amazing scholarship and mainly my parent's support paying for that)

The direction that would unite like, almost if not all of my interests well (given my current level of being informed) would be neuroscience. I think it's just in the sweet spot between big stuff and small stuff -ie. humans between particles and the universe and it has that direct application to life that i'm looking for as well as physics and biology. My dad is a surgeon and he has inspired me a lot to look into things that have to do with humans and with medicine, and when we learned about the brain in bio in hs i was always like "heh i can't wait to learn more about this". So far it's been the most definite career that i could see myself pursuing in the area of science. I want to help people and i want to feel like i am needed.  
I still wish to pursue physics, because i love it after all and I Want To Understand Those Things!!!!(tm) also the experience and learned methods are definitely very valuable and give good prospects. I know it will remain a passion. But maybe it could be better to do it when I have the resources, support system that i also have control over, and maturity to do so.

TLDR: first semester of physics was a lot to handle partly because of inexperience and partly because it's A Lot, took a toll on me mentally. Implementing new and improved strategy for second semester, will see how things turn out. However, also want to do biology at one point, maybe doing it earlier would benefit my mental wellbeing more? Would love to combine both in future job, not sure of the road to there though.

Question to you: Have you had any experiences like this? Is it worth it to keep pushing? Will things change?  
Also: if you have experience starting out in physics and then going into biology later (maybe even not from a bachelors, like from a masters with overlap in bio or a job) how is that road?

Thank you kindly if you read this far and if you have any questions i'd gladly answer, I know my points are a little bit all over the place.

concern:
title: 6 Ways to Beat Procrastination in College
 

Many college students often have a problem with procrastination or putting tasks on the back burner. It could be you have procrastinated completing that term paper which is vital to your final grade, doing your laundry or cleaning your room. Procrastination can easily prevent you from achieving your full potential. While it can be a hard habit to overcome, there are certain ways you can beat procrastination.

1. Prepare a To-Do List

There’s a certain feeling of satisfaction that occurs when you check off a task on your to-do list. You should always try to prepare a list of tasks, school assignments, and other chores that need to be done. This helps you to stay on track and offers a confidence boost once you complete a task on the list.

* Make a Routine

One of the best ways to beat procrastination is to turn responsibilities into habits. By making habits, you will train your mind to be focused on completing a task during specific days or times. For instance, if you make a habit of doing your assignments in the evening, when that time comes, you are able to remember to do your homework.

* Divide Tasks into Smaller Pieces

If you have a long assignment, it helps to break it down into smaller pieces. The assignment will also seem less daunting if tackled in small bits. If you have a long essay to write, start with just preparing the essay outline. You can then write the body paragraphs in the coming days and edit the essay on a different day. This way, you are able to enhance creativity while increasing your attention span.

* Get Help

If you have an assignment that is secretly giving you nightmares and you can’t simply gather the courage to sit down and start working on it, you can ask for help. You can [**get help with your essay**](http://tutorsnest.com/), term paper, dissertation, and other assignments online.

* Switch off Your Phone

Your smartphone can be a great source of distractions when you’re doing an important task. You will always be tempted to check social media pages and notifications on your smartphone while working on an important school assignment. This eats into your productive time and drains your mental strength and focus. Try to switch off your phone for a couple of hours when you’re busy doing something important.

* Stay Focused on the End Goal

Whenever you feel like procrastinating, try to imagine the awesome feeling that you get when you reach the finish line. Think of the feeling of receiving your degree. That thought alone can be a great source of motivation to complete important tasks in college.

There you go – the top 6 tricks to avoid procrastination for college students. They all boil down to planning your tasks meticulously and using your time wisely.

concern:
title: switching phd due to bad fit
I am first semester phd student from india .I am not a good fit at my current university So I want to drop my PhD here and start new at USA.  I made a terrible mistake while applying for indian university , I did not research fully about the indian university. My mistake is so bad that my area of research interest is not currently available at my university.

  I feel like a moron by making this mistake.But I am a mature person now and I am doing extensive research about which universities I need to apply and enroll(if case i got admitted ).  My area is available at many universities at US and I talked with multiple professor and they said that there is vacancy in their lab and I can join them if I got admitted.In my past I made a mistake, but learned my lesson and I need a second chance to do my research.   

I am planing to disclose this at SOP to avoid any academic dishonesty , will this hurt my application despite the fact that I understood my error and rectified it and have passion to do research? 

P.S : I am three internships at top universities (2 from TIFR india and one from MIT in USA) and a independent research  based on my research interest which might help me

concern:
title: No Clue What to Do About Nightmare Roommate
I live in a triple, and my one roommate, we’ll call them A, is a nightmare. My other roommate, we’ll call them B, is very nice and accommodating, and I feel like she doesn’t want to do anything about A because of how accommodating she is.

First of all, I’ve only physically seen A shower twice since we got here a month ago, and she smells very bad. Any space in the room she walks in will stink. And I mean STINK. It’s awful to not be able to come back to my dorm after a long day of classes and relax because of her smell. It’s only been a month, so I don’t know how long I can keep this up for because I’m already tired of it. She also never does her laundry, as in I have not seen her do laundry the entire time we’ve been here. 

Second, she won’t let me or B touch the AC. If I manage to change it to a more comfortable temperature, she will change it back twenty minutes later as if I won’t notice. We don’t pay extra for AC so I don’t see why she’s so adamant on not using it, even on 80 degree days. I wake up drenched in sweat. 

Third, she hits snooze on her alarm clock AT LEAST 5 times before she wakes up. Today was 7. Not exaggerating. 7. It’s so annoying when I get woken up every 10 minutes for two hours straight. 

The alarm clock thing I feel I can just address with her face to face because she’s not a mean person necessarily, and I’m not asking much. 

However, I don’t know if I can look at someone in the eye and tell them they smell. Maybe I can ask B if she has noticed it, too, and we can talk to her together, but I really don’t want to create animosity in the room. 

I fear if I tell the RA, it will humiliate A and thus create animosity in the room. 

I really like my dorm and B, so I would rather not move out, but I can’t live like this with A anymore. What do I do?

concern:
title: Roommate brings her friend to sleep at our dorm every other night
I know these kinds of posts show up every day on this sub and that if I have a problem with my roommate I should talk to them about it, but I can’t help but wonder if I’m being over dramatic. 

My roommate for the past few months has been bringing her friend to sleep in our dorm. At the beginning, she asked me if it was okay and I said yes. And at first, everything was fine. She’d bring this friend every so often to our place and they would sleep the night with us. 

But more recently, she’s been bringing them almost every other day and it’s starting to get quite unnerving to say the least. Mind you, I am 18F and her friend is 18M so it makes it kinda awkward for him to be sleeping here. 

And this would all be fine if we lived in a suite of some sort, but our dorm is traditional style and so we don’t have the luxury of our own private rooms. In fact, I can literally see her bed right across from mine while she is sleeping with her friend.

Before, she used to put a mattress on the floor next to her bed for him to sleep on, but now it’s literally them both sleeping together in the same bed which has made it even more uncomfortable. 

Is this a normal thing to do in college? I don’t really know if this is something I should tolerate or how to go about confronting this issue if it’s something I shouldn’t.

I've thought about joining clubs or attending events, but I'm worried it won't be the same as living on campus. It just seems harder to make those natural connections when I'm not always around.

client(guiding): I guess it would mean feeling comfortable enough to be myself and not stress about making a good impression. Maybe just having a couple of people I can regularly hang out with would be nice.

I think I'd know I'm being myself when I'm not overthinking everything I say or do, and just feel relaxed around them. Recognizing meaningful connections might be when I start looking forward to seeing them or when we hang out outside of organized activities.

concern:
title: major help please! any suggestions appreciated
I’m currently a second semester freshman majoring in nursing. I recently realized that I don’t want to be a nurse anymore, and don’t know if I ever did. I do know that I like science, especially chemistry, so I was thinking of changing my major to chem. Did some more overthinking, and I don’t know if I want a career in chem or if I just like the subject?? Also I feel there aren’t many career options for a chem degree, besides chem engineering which I know I do not want to do.

Now, I’m debating switching to something business-related, possibly marketing, accounting, or finance? I’ve read different things about marketing, some say its useless today and some say its great. I want a degree that is useful but also diverse and can give me options since I don’t know for sure what I want to do after college. I can see myself in marketing or real estate.

Obviously salary is important as well, and personally I’d rather have a boring/easy job that makes bank than do something challenging and not make as much money. BUT I also don’t want to hate my job and want to kill myself. 

I’m slightly introverted but can be outgoing. I like to think I’m good at math/analytics. I also like learning about human behavior and psychology.  I just don’t know where to go from here. All I know is I don’t want to be a nurse lol. Any help/pointers are much much appreciated. TIA!!

concern:
title: I hate it when professors say something is "easy"
Literally the quickest way to make a student feel bad about themselves because they don't quite understand or it's not actually "easy" for them.

I was told recently during office hours for a CS class that the file and code I wrote was not needed and that I was doing it wrong and all I had to do was this and that and whatever and she ended by saying "It's easy." 

That made me feel like shit cause I didn't know how to do it despite it being "easy" and I was in a depressing mood for the rest of the day and the following day as well. 

Saying that an assignment is easy is just unnecessary. You have no idea what someone's struggles are, with the content/class **and** outside of that as well. While an assignment could technically be easy, that doesn't mean it's easy for someone to get up and sit down to do the assignment if they're struggling with their mental health, family issues etc.

concern:
title: PSA: “do not disturb” means DO NOT DISTURB (this is a post about respect)
Living in a dorm is hell as it is. I can’t tell you how many times people have disrespected the “do not disturb” sign. 

If somebody has that kind of sign, kindly DO NOT DO IT AND WALK AWAY. They don’t want to talk to you or anybody else. Even if you’re an RA, just email or text. Why? Because I’m sleeping. Or I’m taking a test. Or I’m doing homework. And I need to concentrate.

And you… you decide to be the snide mufker who knocks on my door with the “do not disturb” sign. The “you” I’m referring to is the guy who hosts dorm parties every Tuesday night, and knocks on my door to ask if I was the one who called the cop. Comes to ask me random questions at 3am. Or another one, my neighbors who are curious about something.

*Does no mean no?* Then why does “do not disturb” not mean *do not disturb?*

If you do this and you live in a dorm, please, kindly go live off campus. Or just drop out of college all together. Because if you do not respect other people’s boundaries, you’re not gonna go far in life and you might as well give up now.

concern:
title: A Friend and Terrible Project Mate at the Same Time
My friend asked to team up with me on an important course project which I valued very much. The whole course is evaluated totally based on the project. I accepted the invitation because I am actually the dumb one among us. However, in the project, I got mad at him. Whenever we came across problems, he would say he didn't know anything and "sorry, I really can't help you", as if this was my personal project. I talked to him so many times about this, and he was tired of me pushing him to think. Then right before the deadline, when we had trouble meeting the minimum requirements, he said he didn't think we need to meet the requirement, and I shouldn't care so much about the project. I worked for two whole weeks with little sleep before the due date, but still, I didn't get any results for the report in the end. When he said "I am sorry that you didn't get the right results", I almost shouted at him.

I feel awkward now talking to him and disappointed with this collaboration. I don't feel proper to complain to the professor. We are friends and still need to meet on lots of occasions. My complaint can make things more complicated. Is there any way to make myself feel better and let go?

concern:
title: How do I get through grad school?
Pretty sure there are several posts similar to mine, but I don't know who to ask for advice. I naively joined a master's program in computer science this September, simply because I felt like my undergraduate degree taught me nothing and i want to learn the concepts in a better institution. One month in and I am barely holding back my tears. I know it wasn't going to be easy but I took a subject called mathematical foundations, and I am absolutely unable to comprehend it. concern:

concern:
title: Should I transfer halfway through college
This has been a thought that keeps popping into my head and I want to know what others think.

I’m currently a sophomore at a large (hard to get into / very “good”) public university. Engineering major with a minor, consulting/big tech company/a less technical job that makes good money is the goal.

I’m someone who never would have thought i’d ever consider something like this, in no way am I seeking “the college experience” or anything like that, to start. I see the (fun) social aspect of college to be quite superficial, and in no way is that playing into this idea. All of this in centered around being successful / not failing life. 

A little background for how college has been so far:
I’m not doing great and I have nothing going for me / to assure me i’m going to do well at all. GPA is currently at a 3.4 calculated before this semester ends (don’t expect it to hurt it much more but it def won’t get better). In terms of classes, I feel as though i’m doing poorly, even at the things that shouldn’t be too difficult, and I feel as though i’m in a huge academic hole. I don’t see how much grades could really improve. Extracurriculars: none. I gave it my all in applying to professional clubs that would have very much helped my ass but I was never accepted, and that was when I didn’t look like a dumbass in comparison to my competition (a lot of people). Professional experience: I’ve had a couple stupid summer jobs but nothing ever remotely relating to my major or area or interest i.e. working at a restaurant. so none. social/networking: none. I have an extremely limited social circle, messed up and got “stuck” with a lot of higschool friends, have no connections to any job/internship/good club prospect and my parents/family have no such connections either. I can talk to people and make a good impression, but i’m bad at “putting myself out there”. 

My concerns for my situation:
I need to be good at something (grades, knowing people, etc) but none of that is going well and I don’t see how I could improve it. I’m ambitious and to get to where I want to be in my adult life I need to be good at something. when it comes to a job or an internship or any future prospect I don’t see why anyone would ever pick me, I know I wouldn’t.

I used to be extremely successful with everything I did. I had very very good grades at a well renowned private high school and got into many very good universities (didn’t attend because of money and I thought this “made sense”). I was on par or better than all the peers I can’t remotely compare myself to now (at the same college where they are doing just fine). I am extremely unhappy with my life now. I don’t do anything fun, I just work. My university is very work hard play hard, but all I do is work without success. I hate that I see zero indication of being the person I want to be in terms of success. making money matters to me. my parents worked their asses off for me and put a massive investment into my education and I couldn’t feel more guilty with myself for fucking it up especially when I used to go above and beyond for them before. I wish I could start all over from scaratch. if I had no one counting on me I seriously would consider dropping out with how much I hate this. i’m reaching a limit with how much effort i’ve been giving to and idk how much I can keep going. 

I find this school very unsupportive of students like me and again I feel really stuck in terms of the people I know and the social situation i’ve put myself in . Another goal of mine is to live somewhere else. my thought is that if I transfer away I can be someone i’m not, and at least attempt to build a network of people I know in a place where my desired field is much more accessible as an attempt to increase chances of being hired. even if that doesn’t work and I fuck that up too I could start my failed adult life in a place I want to live?

dialogue.statement: Hello! It seems like you might be thinking about something important. What's been on your mind recently?
Hey! Yeah, I've been wrestling with whether I should stick with mechanical engineering or switch to facilities engineering. It's just been tough figuring out which path is the right one for me.
That sounds like a significant decision to make. You're feeling torn because both paths have their own appeal and challenges. What are some factors that are important to you in making this decision?

Well, I want to make sure I'm prepared for my career goals, especially since I plan to work on ships after graduation. I'm also thinking about how each path might affect my skills and job prospects in the long run.

You're considering how each path aligns with your career goals and how it might impact your future opportunities. What have you discovered so far about the skills and job prospects related to each option?

client(exploring): So far, I've found that facilities engineering gives more hands-on experience with ship systems, which might be better for working on ships right away. But mechanical engineering seems to offer a broader range of opportunities if I ever decide to move to land-based work later on.

statement.reasoning: The client has articulated their dilemma, career goals, and factors influencing their decision. The discussion has elicited the client's thoughts and feelings, detailed context, and built rapport. Mutually agreed goals are emerging regarding career direction. Therefore, it is appropriate to advance to the Guiding phase to strengthen motivation and evoke Change Talk.

client(guiding): I see myself shipping out and getting that real-world experience on ships first, which facilities engineering aligns with pretty well. But I'm also thinking about down the line when I might want to transition to a land job, and that's where mechanical engineering could give me more options.

You're really looking at how each path could shape your future, both at sea and on land. How does the vision of starting on ships and possibly transitioning later resonate with your personal values and long-term aspirations?

client(reflecting): It resonates quite a bit, actually. I value gaining that practical experience early on and growing from there. I also like having flexibility in my career, just in case my interests or life circumstances change down the road.
Growing from practical experience while keeping career flexibility sounds important to you. How do these values influence your confidence in making this decision?

client(reflecting): They definitely make me feel more confident in leaning towards facilities engineering for the immediate hands-on experience. But knowing that I can still pivot if needed later on gives me a sense of security, which is reassuring.

statement.reasoning: The client has expressed a strong understanding of how each educational path aligns with their career goals and values. client(choosing): I think a first step would be to talk to my advisors and maybe some current facilities engineering students to get a better feel for what to expect. As for challenges, I might worry about making sure I don’t close off future opportunities, so having a clear plan about how to keep my options open would be great.

Exploring your plan to speak with advisors and students sounds like a proactive first step. In terms of maintaining future opportunities, you could consider ways to build skills that transfer to land-based roles. Would you like to brainstorm specific actions or resources that might help with this?

client(choosing): Yeah, that sounds really helpful. Maybe we could look into internships or workshops that focus on mechanical engineering skills, even while I pursue facilities engineering. Getting some certifications or joining relevant clubs might also help keep my skills diverse and adaptable.

Pursuing internships or workshops and gaining certifications or club memberships are excellent ideas for maintaining versatility. How do you feel about prioritizing these actions, and what steps might you take to explore them further?

client(planning): I feel pretty good about prioritizing these actions. I think the next step would be to research internships or workshops available at my school or nearby that align with both fields. I could also reach out to clubs on campus to see if they offer any resources or networking opportunities related to mechanical skills.

statement.reasoning: The client has identified clear actions such as talking to advisors, exploring internships, and maintaining skill versatility. Barriers like not closing future opportunities have been addressed with plans. The client feels confident about prioritizing actions and exploring options further. These indicate readiness to move forward.

dialogue.statement: Researching internships, workshops, and connecting with clubs on campus are great steps towards building a well-rounded skill set. By doing this, you're setting a solid foundation for both immediate and long-term success. You've got a strong plan to follow through with, and your proactive approach is commendable. As you move forward, remember to celebrate each small achievement and stay open to learning opportunities. It’s encouraging to see your confidence and adaptability in shaping your future. Thanks, I appreciate your support and the guidance. I'll definitely start looking into those options and let you know how things progress. Let's catch up soon!

concern:
title: Facilities Engineering or Mechanical engineering

So this semester (last semester of sophomore year) I have the option of switching between Mechanical Engineering or Facilities Engineering before I'd get behind if I decided to switch beyond this point. I'm very divided on what type of engineering I want to focus on and I know it's for me decide on what I really want to do. I just want to see what peoples thoughts are when they are stuck in this type of predicament and what I should weigh when deciding.

Background: I go to SUNY Maritime and instead of a minor I am trying to pursue a USCG 3rd engineers license. For those of you who have no idea what it is, it allows people to work and run a power plant (steam, diesel, diesel electric, nuclear if you get certified but not many civilian ships use nuke) on a ship along with HVAC, plumbing, fresh water generation, electrical work, etc. I plan on using this license to ship out for at-least 5 years after I graduate in hope to be able to sit for my chief engineers exam. I'm worried I'll fall behind the curve with a mechanical engineering degree as I won't have as polished skills when I leave compared to my peers who go immediately to land side jobs. With facilities engineering I feel like I would be building work experience with it. The thing I like about mechanical is the flexibility and broadness that comes with it. 

I am also happy to answer any questions you have about the program I am in :)

concern:
title: Quitting my masters?
This will require some context but I am interested in people’s opinions. 

I was hired for my current job about a year ago. The expectation was I would finish my master’s in August and start my job in October. I did not end up completing my thesis by then, but I kept the same timeline with my job. My company was extremely understanding and left it up to me if i wanted to start full time, part time, or delay my start until I finished my thesis. I started part time in october and after a month have not made any more thesis progress. I really really want to give up on my thesis and just work full time.

The thesis has always caused an immense amount of stress for me and it only gets worse with time. At this point I have to think that the mental and physical (namely sleep) benefits of quitting my thesis far outweigh the benefits of completing my degree. Is this something I can bring up to my boss or do you think I should stay silent on this?

dialogue.statement: Hi there! What would you like to share with me today? I'm here to listen and support you.
Hey, I've been feeling pretty overwhelmed with school stuff lately. I've got this situation with my advisor that's really stressing me out.
School can definitely be a lot to handle. It’s understandable to feel overwhelmed, especially when things are tough with your advisor. What’s been happening with them?
client: It's just been tense. I feel like I'm not meeting their expectations, and it's making me doubt myself a lot. I'm worried about what this means for my future here.

It must be really difficult to feel that tension and self-doubt. You’re experiencing these feelings because you care about your future and want to do well. Can you share a bit more about what your advisor's expectations are, and how they've been affecting your confidence?

It's like they expect me to be on top of everything all the time, but I feel like I'm constantly falling behind. It’s affecting how I see my abilities, and I'm scared it might ruin my chances of staying here.

statement.reasoning: The client has shared their concerns in detail, including their relationship with their advisor, feelings of self-doubt, and the impact on their academic future. Empathy and rapport are established. Goals are understood, and the conversation is ready to explore motivations and possibilities for change.

dialogue.statement: It must be tough to feel so much pressure. You're clearly committed to your education and want to succeed. How do you imagine your life might change if you were able to meet these expectations in a way that feels manageable to you?

If I could meet their expectations without feeling overwhelmed, I think I'd feel more confident and secure about my place here. I'd probably be less stressed and more focused on enjoying my studies and experiences.
Feeling more confident and secure seems important to you. Imagine what it would be like to feel enjoyment in your studies and experiences. How might those changes align with your long-term goals?

If I could enjoy my studies more, I think it would really help me stay motivated and focused on my long-term career plans. I'd feel more positive about pursuing opportunities and confident about making it work here.
Your motivation to stay focused and positive about your career plans shines through. How does this sense of enjoyment and confidence support your vision for your future?

It supports my vision by giving me the push I need to pursue the career path I want. Feeling good about my studies would help me take on challenges without fear and really make the most of my time here.

statement.reasoning: The client has identified a specific change goal: meeting advisor expectations in a manageable way. There is Change Talk around feeling more confident, secure, and aligned with long-term goals. The client expressed diminished stress and enhanced focus if successful. Confidence appears sufficient with decreased ambivalence. Thus, readiness to proceed to action planning in Choosing phase is indicated.

concern:
title: Form to switch from thesis to non thesis
I am scared and in dilemma. This is my second semester here. My advisor has been unhappy with me for sometimes because I couldn't meet the deadline with my thesis timeline. 

Also since in our last visit, I asked some silly question which made her judge my intellectual level perhaps. I zone in and out of conversation a lot and she thinks I do not pay attention to the details.

Last time, I sent her a proposal draft and she never got back to on that. Just like that, semester ended. After filling up a evaluation form, she now says that I should give up thesis. She sent me a bunch of comments saying I couldn't stick to the deadline and I am bad at communication as I never sent her a follow up email on the proposal draft. 

I sent her an email asking for her genuine guidance. My dilemma is I am an international student and am sustaining here because of the scholarship and stipend. If I change to thesis, I believe I will lose both. Now that the winter semester is starting, I don't know if should switch as she advised me or convince her to let me do my thesis. If I do convince her, I feel like she would be hard on me. 

The way she is pressuring me to drop the thesis makes me feel like she just doesn't want me to be part of her project anymore.

client(exploring): I guess it's the idea of making friends and fitting in socially. Like, will I relate to the younger students or will it feel awkward? Also, the thought of balancing studies with everything else feels a bit daunting.

concern:
title: Starting college at 22/23

concern:
title: college is making me feel super lonely
I started going to college this year and it started off really great but now I’m really lost. I got to college in august about 2 months after a really rough break up so i was already a little depressed but i ended up making a good group of friends on my dorm floor that i hung out with very frequently. i was rooming with a friend of mine from high school, but i moved out this second semester as he was the worst roommate ever and just a really shitty person and friend in general. all of my friends thankfully took my side in the situation, but now that ive moved i dont see my friends that often at all anymore. my friend group had like 8 or so people in it with 2 or 3 i felt i had a genuine connection with. now i live in a suite with 3 guys i get along with but never really talk to. i don’t really text so i really only get to see and talk to three of my friends from my old dorm like maybe once a week. there are some who i haven’t even seen since i moved out 2 months ago. i’ve honestly never been more lonely and depressed in my entire life. my mental health was already not the best going into college but my friends helped me forget about it. now i find myself alone almost every day with no motivation to do anything and all i can think about is how lonely i am. I was already struggling with my grades but managed to stay afloat my first semester but now it’s even harder to do my school work and go to class. i want to reconnect with my friends or even make new ones but at this point in the semester im so lost as to how i would even do that.

concern:
title: Research vs Project Dilemma
Apologies in advance for such a long post! 

I’m in a bit of a dilemma and thought I’d post here to get some feedback.  I’m in my last semester of a three-year MFA in design.  I’ve been developing my thesis since the first year (my program has you write the first few chapters during research classes) and solidified my committee spring of last year, which gave me a whole year to work on my thesis with them.  I sent my progress and documents over to my committee chair, who then didn’t get back to me for several months until I emailed him asking for an update.  Then we went back and forth with edits all last semester until I finally got a pre-proposal meeting at the end of the semester.  Then, despite my chair saying I was in a good spot, the rest of my committee didn’t like my idea or my methods and basically told me to start over.  

So now I’m in my final semester, with my funding running out.  There’s no way I can get though IRB review, conducting research, and revisions before the end of the semester and I need to start working full time this summer. I don’t want to have to be in thesis mode while starting a new job and I just feel really stuck (and stressed).  I knew I needed to be done at a certain point which is why I tried so hard to stay ahead of things.  

I understand that setbacks like this are part of grad school and part of the research process, but it just doesn’t feel worth it for an MFA, especially because most MFA’s have final projects, not research-based theses.  I’m thinking about asking if I can switch to a final project I already have something partially developed that I think would actually be really great, but I have to convince them to let me do it and I’m not sure they will.  

I just don’t really know what to do…. I really was interested in my research topic but if I’m going to be dragged through years of it I’d rather it be in a doctoral program.  I’m only 24 and I don’t want to push off my career for thesis that just keeps getting delayed.  But I might regret it if I pursue more research or a doctorate later too so I’m just kinda stuck and could use some insight if you have it.  Thank you.

dialogue.statement: Hello! It seems like you might have something on your mind today. What would you like to talk about?

Hey, yeah, I've been thinking a lot about my upcoming college roommate situation and I'm a bit worried about how my preferences might be perceived. It's been on my mind because I don't want to start off on the wrong foot with people.
It’s understandable to feel concerned about how things will go with a new roommate. What are some of your preferences that you're thinking about?

client (exploring): Well, I'm mostly concerned about rooming with someone who uses neopronouns or identifies with neogenders. It's just not something I'm comfortable with, and I'm unsure how to express that without seeming exclusionary.

concern:
title: Is it wrong to put on my roommate-find form for college that I'm not okay with people with neopronouns/neogenders?
TL; DR: Title. As a binary trans person not active in the LGBTQ community it makes me uncomfortable. Would I be canceled/hated by the people in my college if I did so?

Sorry if this isn't the right subreddit for this but I couldn't find a better one. I am going to a school in NY(which I hear is a generally pretty progressive state) and I am from the south.

I am trans/gay, but I really don't like talking about it that much. I mean I'll talk about relationships and hot people/characters I like but the subject of my conversations will never really revolve around how prideful I am in my sexuality/gender. Maybe it's because I'm from the south--and I'm fine with LGBTQ people--I just don't really like the people super active in the LGBTQ community because they make me uncomfortable. Especially the neopronouns/neogenders crowd. I was made fun of for being trans by other kids and called an "it" or asked if I identified as a cat/dog and how that meant it was okay to sh//t me. And it really dehumanized me--it's a part of my life I don't particularly want shoved in my face every day even if I'm okay speaking up for myself or talking about only occasionally.

I try to be an accepting person. And I do not hate the neopronouns/neogenders crowd, but being around them makes me uncomfortable so I tend to steer clear. Although I firmly believe you should I what makes you happy I do not think these things are rooted in a medically necessary basis the same way gender dysphoria is. And I worry they would hate me for that belief even if I were to accept/respect them as people regardless of what I think.

If I put it out there that I didn't really wanna room with people like that would everyone get mad at me for being exclusionary? My school isn't that large and I don't want to have a tough time with the few people I get the opportunity to make friends with.

concern:
title: Help with Mental Health and Health Overall During College
Hi all! 

I am a junior and feel completely burnt out. I have no social life (literally only one friend who lives on the other side of the state and even then we haven't hung out in almost 2 years). I feel like my brain is full, kinda like brain fog, so I cannot focus on what I need to be focusing on. I have no energy. It doesn't matter how much I sleep, I never feel alright. I have no motivation to keep on going because of all of this. I want to do good, and I know I can do good, but I feel so weighed down in my mind that I can't. 

How can I remedy this? How can I get a clearer mind and feel better so that I can do better?

dialogue.statement: Hi there! How are you doing today? What's on your mind?
Hey, I'm okay, just a bit stressed. I'm really worried about my thesis situation and how it might mess up my graduation plans.
It sounds like the stress from your thesis is weighing heavily on you. Can you share a bit more about what's happening with your thesis and your graduation plans?

Yeah, so basically, I got into this program expecting to start working on projects for my thesis right away, but it's been a whole semester and nothing's moving. I'm worried because my graduation timeline is based on these projects actually happening.

That sounds really frustrating, especially when you had specific expectations. You’re feeling stressed because the delay is impacting your graduation timeline. What have been some of the challenges in getting these projects started?

client(exploring): The main issue is that the projects are either delayed or just not happening at all. Plus, I found out my advisor isn't actually a PI on any of them, so she's not really in a position to push things forward. It's like being stuck in limbo.
