Sounds like having your projects move forward would bring a sense of relief and accomplishment, aligning more with your graduation goals. What would it mean for you to regain some control over this situation?

client(reflecting): Regaining control would definitely ease a lot of my stress. It would mean I could actually plan my next steps and feel like I'm on track with my goals, rather than just waiting around and hoping something changes.

Feeling more in control seems really important to you, especially in aligning with your graduation goals. How confident do you feel, on a scale from 0 to 10, about finding ways to regain some control over your thesis situation?

client(reflecting): I'd say maybe a 4 or 5 right now. I know there might be some things I can try, but I'm not sure how much influence I'll actually have in changing the situation. It's a bit daunting, to be honest.

concern:
title: Any Red Flags I Missed?
Hi all, 

I'm in a thesis STEM MS where the professors/PIs largely choose students instead of having students rotate in labs or reach out to potential PIs. I was brought in to work on a few collaborative projects where the PIs and my advisor are not the same people. This was never mentioned to me, and I happened to find out when an undergrad and I were talking. For various reasons, any and all projects I was supposed to use for my thesis are either disjointed, have been delayed, or will no longer happen (it's been an entire semester and I've done no work on anything). Turns out my advisor merely "consults" on 1 of them and failed to mention she is not a PI on any project right now, is powerless to move them along, and seems to care a little less every day. This is slowly becoming more of an issue that could possibly keep me from graduating on time. 

Is any of this unusual, or is it just how it goes in academia sometimes? Is having an advisor who is not my PI problematic?

dialogue.statement: Hello! How are you doing today? Feel free to share whatever's on your mind. I'm here to listen.
Hey, thanks for asking. I've been feeling really overwhelmed with school lately, like everything's just too much. I've been thinking a lot about taking a break to focus on myself.

It sounds like the demands of school are really weighing on you, leading you to consider taking a break to take care of your well-being. What aspects of school are making you feel most overwhelmed right now?

client(exploring): It's mostly the people, to be honest. I feel like I don't fit in with my classmates and my professors just add to the stress. Plus, the workload is never-ending, and I just feel burnt out.

concern:
title: Help me decide on a lab!
So I have two labs, A and B. Our program (bio) makes us rotate prior to choosing our thesis lab. 
I’m really, really passionate about A’s research. A is a really good lab, PI has tons of funding, great connections, great facility, awards, etc. I rotated with A, told me to go rotate with C as well since they collaborate on the project I want to join. A is also really competitive to get into, so I agreed to rotate with C in a few weeks, even though it’s an engineering lab which I’m not into at ALL, but thought maybe it’ll help me understand A’s research better. Now I learn that if I join I might need to do a comentoring situation with both A and C which I’m really not into since I don’t want to get into biomedical engineering. Theoretically I could ask to stay solely in A if I don’t end up liking C when I rotate, but I’m not sure if that’ll seem odd since I agreed to rotating with C and if it will lower my chances of getting into A. Also, I’m not really a fan of the lab environment in A, it hasn’t been super welcoming from the other grad students, but the PI is a good mentor. I won’t get a lot of guidance since she wants independence, but I feel like it will be hard but make me a “better scientist.” Also, the PI will be retiring when the grant that I’m joining will finish, so theoretically we would be leaving at the same time, which I’m not sure if that’s a problem. 

On the other hand, B is a good lab, has a great lab culture, I enjoy the methods used, really sweet PI that I feel comfortable asking questions to. BUT I’m not into the overall research topic at all, and really don’t want to be stuck in that field, and when I think about research I’m SO much more into A’s research. 

TLDR: Which lab should I join? The lab that checks all the boxes but I don’t like the research, or the one I really like the research, but has a lot of other problems

concern:
title: Having no friends
I started college a couple of months ago, and I moved from a different country so i had to leave all my friends that i had. I've never had any issues with making friends, I think at the beginning of starting a new school I've always been worried about making friends but it just... happened. concern:
title: Do not forget: College is a business.
Always remember that college is a business and it does not have your best interest in mind. 

Most people go to college to study something they like and then they try to find a job. THIS IS THE WRONG APPROACH!!…

The right approach is to find a job that u would like to do in the future and then decide which is the path of least resistance that can get u there. 

Remember: Going to college is a financial decision before anything else. 

Bonus Advice: Advisor are not reliable, free online PDF books exist and most employers do not care about the school u when.

concern:
title: Should I drop out of my Summer class?
I (20f) only have to do one more math class to get my general 2 year degree, however all the summer classes at my community college are only online for summer quarter. Math is my worst subject so this is very alarming, but I signed up for one online however I'm finding it extremely difficult to grasp the concepts through videos, and typing my answers is extremely stressful. There are a lot of really good in person classes for the fall, but my parents are really looking forward to me graduating by the end of Summer.

My goal is to be hired and go to the police academy by fall and be graduated by August. I don't need a degree to be hired, but it would look better on my application and possibly give me a small pay boost if I'm hired. I really don't want to disappoint my family, but at the same time I'm very concerned and don't want to end up failing. I also need to build muscle for the physical test, but I haven't had the time due to work and classes. I've never been good at online classes (my grades were the worst during the pandemic) and the tutors at my college seem very busy when I go there. What's the right thing to do?

Edit: Thank you all so much. I'm going to try and power through it. :)

concern:
title: Job prospects for a non-clinical masters or PhD in psychology?
Originally I did not want to go to school for non-clinical degree but after much discussion with advisors i ended up in a non-clinical psychology phd.  I have regular doubts about if this was the right choice.  

Currently have almost completed the masters portion of my program.  

It honestly feels like the longer i am here the more I doubt my decision to come here.  I feel like I had a lot of passion prior to coming here that school has now squashed.  

I was always encouraged to just pursue my area of interest and I think the general area of research i am interested in but it i feel like I was deceived about the nature of the program and the research I would be allowed to do.

Its never been clear exactly what job prospects exist and anytime i talk to someone I get told wildly different things and I dont really know what to believe anymore.

Anyways any thoughts are much appreciated.  Thank you for your time.

concern:
title: Feeling lost
Just started my first semester of college this spring because I felt lost and left behind in the fall, now that I’m here I am realizing that I have no plan for anything going forward. It feels like Everyone around me very meticulously plotting their next step while I am jumping before thinking. I am leaning towards majoring in business or history but I’m sure that’s not what I really want to do. I feel lost and confused and like this is the hardest part of my life. I don’t know where to go or where to turn. Everyone who I try to talk to this about is unable to help in any way other than telling me it’s okay. concern:
title: Is anyone else struggling with feeling aimless during summer?
Hi there, 20F here
Just wondering how you all fare during the summer. My last final was three weeks ago, and I just finished junior year. I work very hard and do well in school, but once it ends and I go from a rigid structure to nothing I feel disoriented and directionless.

Part of it is that I feel the need to be constantly making progress. Another part is that I am pressuring myself to be figuring out my career path, because I hate not knowing exactly what I want to do. I'm good at school, but I'm also afraid that I won't be good at working and applying my skills to practical situations.

Some of these fears are irrational--I've worked before, I've done great and I've discovered some aspects of my career that I like and dislike. I want to explore the medical field but I'm not sure if I could be hired for only 3-4 months as an entry level worker and then leave to go back to school.

Basically summer gives me lots of generalized anxiety about my life and future that I don't have time to stew on during the school year. I know the obvious solution is to make arrangements for summer plans ahead of time so I don't run into this, but I had a short term change in my living situation and so I'm in a new place away from my university and feeling like everything is unfamiliar.

So much empty time and I'm not sure what to do with it.

concern:
title: So I’ve started college but I want a change
I’m a first year student who’s recently finished summer school and overall I’ve enjoyed my time at university, but I honestly don’t think it’s for me. That’s not to say that I want to drop out, but I was hoping to get a full time job and take classes online instead. Also, I don’t have a car or any other sort of transportation besides walking or being driven around by a relative’s vehicle, so honestly, I don’t have reliable transportation when I’m at school. This is why I’d rather stay at home. 

Anyway, if that doesn’t work, I was thinking about just going back to cc (which was supposed to happen in the first place), but my family is pretty against me doing that and believe that I would be selling myself short by doing so. I’ve also considered dropping out as well because the major that I have chosen doesn’t seem to be a proper choice and it may not help me in the long run (elementary education). I’d rather not waste anyone’s time and money, you know? 

Then also there are some things in my personal life that I haven’t shared with my family and I’m unsure that if it ever comes up in conversation or I decide to tell them, then they’ll stop helping me pay for school. That’s why I wanted to get a job just in case something were to happen and they decide not to help anymore. 

Not sure what to do anymore :(

concern:
title: How To Manage My Classes?
Hello, I’m currently taking 2 online classes while I work full time at a community college. I’m excited that I’m going to college but it’s getting really hard to the point that I’m falling behind in both classes. I have an F and a D in both classes (Art and Math). I’m afraid that even if I pass these classes, I would have to cram all my work. Like I don’t want to my foundational thinking to be screwed or messed up in my future college classes.

I plan to transfer to a 4 year, the music class is a class necessary for the transfer while the math is not, but it is a prerequisite to the class that will transfer so I’m more worried about that. Should I drop the music class? Or am I just being overwhelmed by the such limited time I have to do assignments? I’m also assuming that since both classes are online, theres more of a workload since my professors are giving me everything all at once? I’m in my early 20’s and I’m having to do a bit of extra time and effort to make up what I’ve lost especially in my math class.

My goal is to pass with A’s but I feel that in order to do so, I would need to cram all the work in and not actually “learn” or “retain” the information for future classes. Has anyone had a rough start to college even if it’s online?

concern:

concern:
title: Im unhappy with my college and its location, but is it worth leaving
I’m currently a 18M freshman at Parsons The New School of Design in NYC as a Communication Design major (graphic design). This has been my dream school since I was 10 years old but unfortunately after being here for almost 2 semesters, I don’t like it. The classes aren’t as engaging/ geared towards my field of study as I hoped they would be. I find myself being forced to take a lot of useless classes when I could be taking more graphic design oriented courses. 
I’m from Connecticut and used to a suburban lifestyle. I enjoy having the option of driving my car places. I thought the New York lifestyle would be something new and exciting for me because it’s something i’ve always dreamed of, however I just don’t seem to fit in. It’s not enjoyable for me and im usually scared anywhere I go after dusk. It’s very hard to make friends here, and having that handicap has made it hard to venture out and enjoy the city. I feel very alone and isolated here. However, New York is an amazing place for opportunities, especially in the art field, and I’m wondering if i’m throwing away my dream/ chances at a good job by moving back to Connecticut to go to an art school there? I don’t know what jobs would be available for me in CT, and i’m worried i’ll fail and not make money if I move back there. Should I find a way to enjoy New York so I can continue going to school here, or should I move to somewhere I’m comfortable? Is New York really worth the job opportunities for graphic design artists?

concern:
title: afraid of no college experience at cc pls don’t hate
i start my freshmen year of community college this month and im looking forward to it but also not since i already know the bad that comes from it. for ex: 

•no social life 
•NO COLLEGE EXPERIENCE 
•possibility of having a full class with middle aged parents/ business workers that randomly wanted to be in school again
• watching all my friends and mutuals have fun at their university that i also wanna attend to etc.
•being stuck in my room doing nothing etc 

i personally want to go to community for just one year then transfer and i know it’s harder that way if you don’t get your full 60 credits and transfer as a junior but why would i want to waste all my time at cc and possibly only have 1.5 years to enjoy myself at a uni??? community isn’t best for me but im only doing it because my high school gpa would not have gotten me into a uni and i do regret it because i skipped a lot or had very very bad mental health days so now i have to deal with the consequences and so community is really my only route for right now. and it sucks knowing that I won’t have the experience i want I know you’re thinking “the experience isn’t the main important thing just transfer in 2 years it’s not big deal plUs yOuR SavIng moNey” yeah I’ve read other reddit threads of teens expressing their same feelings that i have and it’s a bunch of the middle aged adults saying the same thing. let’s be honest here im 18 and so are the other peers that feel this way that are around the ages of 17-23 ofc we want to live a little and are pissed about having to be at community while everyone else is having fun. also you may know this but for some people university is their only escape route from home/toxic homes/ or just tired of being in their city cause they’ve been their all they’re life. it’s hardening to see and also i don’t live close to my community at all so it’s gonna be HELL trying to get there and back, my parents don’t own a car and i don’t trust a uber either. i just know this is gonna be one hell of a first year. any advice on how to deal through this? how i can make friends easier? concern:
title: Weird professor. not sure what to do
i’m a 4th year student and i’m taking a class that’s required for graduation with a professor i took 2 summers ago for an online class. that summer i had a rough time and was going through some things, and my professor was very understanding and kind. he was quick to respond to emails and worked with giving me extensions and stuff, and after the class ended we periodically emailed about school and life and i always thought he was very kind and compassionate. he has great ratings on rate my professor and up until now i have never felt uncomfortable or creeped out by him. as time went on, the emails from him became more consistent and long. this man would write me novels and send random “how are you doing” at 12 and 1am. well, last spring he recommended me for a scholarship and to be in a mentor program and one day i was on campus and decided to stop by his class quickly to formally introduce myself in person and thank him for the opportunity. i then received and email almost immediately after and one of the BOLD captions was “Meeting you: please do not be offended” and he went on to talk about how beautiful i was on the inside and out and how my eyes were beautiful (all in the school email, and i was wearing a mask). fast forward to now, i have him in person on mondays and wednesdays and in class yesterday he was staring at my the entire lecture and he emailed me today and was talking about my looks and that he “loved” seeing me in class. sometimes if i take too long to reply to the emails he will say something like “i miss our emails” like bro is down bad and also married with 4 kids. the biggest downfall is that i have had many opportunities open up because of his recommendations and i plan on going to law school and could really use him for that but i also have an entire semester of class with him and i feel like he’s undressing me with his eyes every time i see him so i don’t know what to do 🥴

concern:
title: Mid-college crisis?
Hi. I hope I can explain this correctly. I just have this weird feeling and I'm wondering if anyone is experiencing the same. 

I'm a sophomore. It's my second semester (as I'm sure it is for most). I did my first freshman semester at an online community college, then transferred to university. I'm at a weird "mid-college" crisis, I guess? It feels like time has just flashed by; I'm already almost a junior. But, at the same time, I'm only almost a junior, if that makes sense. It feels like I don't have much time left in my college career, but also, I know that realistically, I have at least two years (especially since I'm considering grad school) left. I'm literally only 19, and I also know that I have a lot of time after college to experience life before I decide to settle down, but I also feel like I've not taken advantage of the time I've had before. 

It's weird. I'm in a weird spot with my credits, and have been relentlessly pushing myself to fix the situation, so it feels like I haven't really experienced the less-academically-important-but-equally-mentally-important (in my opinion) aspect of socialization as much as I should have. I don't have many friends, but recently, for whatever reason, I've been really trying to get out of my shell and explore new things and make new friends. I don't know what came over me to do this, and I kinda wish I did this sooner. I guess I always thought it would happen naturally. I dunno. In high school, as a sophomore, I couldn't wait to graduate and be done. But now, as a sophomore in college, I feel the same, but I also simultaneously feel the opposite. I don't really want to join a frat or anything, and I've met people from mutual hobbies and clubs (as well as recently meeting up with some people from my university Discord server), but I dunno. I feel like I should've done more, and now that I'm approaching upper division college, I'll need to focus more on career and professional stuff. 

Is this weird? Does anyone feel the same or have had similar experiences?

concern:
title: Advice - PI Preventing Me From Changing Labs
Hi all! So I've been trying to change labs for a bit now. My relationship with my advisor has gone from bad to worse and the relationship can no longer be salvaged. For the past few months, my PI has repeated refused to support any accomplishment or research venture I had. The PI doesn't even fund any part of my PhD as I am a fellow in a dry lab with no resource costs. Even my conferences, poster printing, and publications I've had to pay for out of pocket. 

Recently, I began speaking to a new PI in my department about changing to their lab. They were initially supportive of it but just wanted to make sure things were cool with my current PI before I changed. I let my current PI know I was planning on changing labs and made the commitments to finish up all the pending work on a paper I was working on with them as a corresponding before leaving the lab. The current PI said they understood and supported the move. This was surprising but didn't think anything else of it. A few days past and now the new PI has pulled back their support after speaking to my current PI. I spoke to my current PI today and they sounded pleased with themselves regarding me not being able to leave. They gave me an ultimatum which drastically limits my dissertation if I wanted to stay in their lab after all of this. I'm sure the current PI (who is know for being petty and spiteful) meddled and prevented my change from going through. 

The lab I was hoping to change into is the closest to what I'd like to do for my PhD at my school. My current PI has essentially put me being a rock and a hard place, making me chose between either continuing under them with major re-shifting of my dissertation, or leaving the program entirely. I don't know how I can possibly salvage the relationship with the other PI I wanted to change to in the hopes of changing to them still. It feels like I'm a prisoner of my PI. Any advice?

concern:
title: how did you guys choose your major?
so apparently, I finished my exams and got 84%. in my country, applying to universities depends on the mark you get. apparently I really don't know what should I do. I don't like med school so we leave this option behind. I'm interested in engineering, literally any engineering field but specifically rn I have mechatronics engineering in mind. my parents on the other hand don't really support my decision about engineering. universities are completely free, except for the private universities of course. my parents want to get me into a private university but tbh my family is not that financially stable and my parents already have plans of moving out of our apartment, get a house and a new car. I really don't want to trouble them with my uni fees especially that they've spent 7000$ on my tuitions and school stuff. my boyfriend is saying that this is an opportunity that I shouldn't miss but he doesn't get it, his family is rich and they plan on sending him to study medicine in another country so he doesn't understand why I feel so guilty. my mom said I should study English and since I'm already good at it I won't have much trouble. to me, I'm flexible, I don't mind studying anything but it's still a hard decision to make

edit: I really didn't think anyone would notice this post but I need to thank you all. I read every single comment and they're all so helpful. the reason I don't have a major in my mind is because I'm good at any subject in hand and maybe, just maybe because my parents always decided everything on my behalf lol. My parents are against engineering is because they believe I'm a lazy one and won't be able to put up with how hard it is all because of my high school grades (apparently i have adhd and depression but im off meds which affected my grades). I know there's nothing like an easy major and that's what I've been trying to tell them but yeah. my mother only suggested studying English so I could be an English teacher. i mentioned that in my country we can apply to universities depending on our marks, the less you get the less options you have. also studying in another country or in another city in my country is not an option lol. again, thanks a lot for your help

concern:
title: Stressing out over inconsistent grading
I did really well as an undergrad. If I put the effort in and listened to feedback, I'd get a good grade. If I tried to wing it, I'd get a bad grade. I got a top mark on my dissertation that year and felt good going into my masters.

I'm at a new uni this year and my grades are always either very high or very low. I was just given feedback on a presentation I did, and one of the comments left for me was that I should be more thoughtful as a grad student, with no further context. I was also marked down for following the outline provided to us and not adding additional slides, which we weren't asked to do. This was one of 3 assignments we were given over Christmas, during which time staff were on leave and not answering emails. I'm losing respect for my instructors, and I am kind of dreading beginning my dissertation. This presentation was a proposal for my dissertation, and based on the grading, my advisor and the instructor who grades the papers are not on the same page.

I don't know if I'm just being a baby over this, but I feel like I can't anticipate what my instructors are looking for and I'm worried about my dissertation. I have a few friends in the class who are getting similar marks and I know they're putting huge efforts into their assignments. At this point, I just want to pass and get my degree.

dialogue.statement: Hello! I'm here to listen and support you. What's on your mind today?

Hey, so I've been wrestling with this decision about whether to stick with an associates in arts or switch to an associates in science. My advisor has one opinion, but I feel like the science path aligns more with my interests in computers.

It can be challenging to weigh different opinions, especially when they come from people you trust. You're drawn to the science path because of your interest in computers. What are some thoughts or concerns you have about making that switch?

concern:
title: Engineering —> Psychology
I’m starting university this Fall, in Mechanical Engineering. I chose it because I liked woodworking and metalworking in high school, and thought it’d be a stable career.  

However, I have pretty split interests. Before I settled on an Engineering start, I was also considering English, Political Science, or Psychology. Thinking practically, for my situation I’ve ruled out English and Poli Sci as degree prospects, but am still curious about Psychology.

Only thing is, I’m aware that I might like it in theory, but that it might not be a feasible career. My plan is to explore it as a minor after talking to my advisor, but I’m not sure how close to the actual major that would be. Plus, I’ve had college students tell me that minors in a different field than your major can often deviate your focus.

So Psychology majors, do you think it’s worth such a big switch? Pros and cons of the major?

—

EDIT: Thanks so much everyone for the insight! I see now that a degree in Psychology, while versatile, is most effective with a PhD or some sort of further study behind it, but on its own can be difficult to hold down a career with. I’ll stick with Engineering, but will continue to explore Psych as a minor/hobby, and will look into human psychology aspects of Engineering/A.I. going down the line as well. 

Thanks again, I’m excited to see what comes of this!!

concern:
title: Grad school or Gap Year Abroad?
My main question is pretty obvious from the title, but I’ll give a little more context here. 

I’m about to graduate from undergrad with a BSE in English. I’m also completing a senior thesis and getting certified to teach middle through high school English. Right now I’m looking through graduate schools, prepping for the GRE, and working on thesis, but the more I look into the programs I’m interested in, the more I’m realizing I will likely not be accepted. 

The biggest reason is the language requirement. Most of the programs require fluency in another language upon entry. However, others require it by the end of the first year, meaning you’ll have to start at an intermediate level upon entry. I was originally minoring in Spanish, but for many reasons I won’t go into, I had to drop it. I picked up a Writing Studies minor instead, but now looking at Graduate programs in Comparative Literature/Cultural Studies/etc. that I’m interested in, I know I should’ve gotten that minor in Spanish. However, I don’t have space in my schedule to make up all those credits in my last year. I also can’t afford summer classes. For the few programs that don’t require you to come in fluent, I’d technically only need one other Spanish class to meet their requirements. 

However to top it all off, I’d actually prefer to learn a different language. I would still love to learn Spanish at some point, but my undergrad thesis is focused on Chinese American literature. I’d prefer to focus the rest of my graduate studies on that field. My university only offers French and Spanish, so I’m out of luck there. 

This brings me to my question. Should I apply for graduate programs, cramming in some beginning Chinese program during the summer through CIEE or something similar through my university’s study abroad to bring me to the bare minimum intermediate level? Or should I take a gap year studying abroad to gain a much higher level of fluency, take a break, and give myself more time to consider all my options? I’m afraid of what Graduate admissions will think if I take a year off, and there’s always the possibility that I won’t be accepted or be able to afford a year studying abroad. It could end up being thousands of dollars in debt wasted when I should’ve just gone straight into grad school. 

Any advice is welcome. Even if you think I should suck it up and just take the Spanish course!

concern:
title: Tips on overcoming burnout + anxiety over previous semester results
long tory short I had a pretty traumatic previoos semester (went through a miscarriage and a bad breakup all within the last 6-7 weeks of school) and might have fumbled my first semester of the year cause my mental health went to shit and I felt so burntout by the time exam's had rolled around - I didn't work as hard as l should've/would've under normal circumstances. 

this week is the first week of my second semester of the year and although I feel mentally stronger than I did previously & actually quite determined to deal with the semester, im also experiencing extreme crippling anxiety over my performance and results of the previous semester (like I literally can't bring myself to open my student email and today, which was the first day of school, I just sat in my car in the uni carpark for almost 2 hours before ultimately driving home because I was afraid to see my peers & lecturers - I don't know why lol). i really don't want to let the burnout i experienced in the previous semester & thr anxiety over it all spill over into the present and affect my studies this semester. 

any tips on getting over burnout as well as dealing with/letting go of anxiety surrounding performance in the previous semester?

concern:
title: I am out
4am and I can't sleep. I'm drafting an email for the one class I can't auto pilot. I'm workshopping the nicest ways to say "I don't got it in me, thanks so much, but I'm taking leave for at least a year and don't have the will to finish strong. You can be nice and accommodate me or don't and I'll just fail." 

Have to take off to help family. Pretty likely I can get rehired as a TA and finish after, but, still. Feeling ambivalent, low, blech. 

Anybody else taken a grad gap year? I don't have feasibility questions, I know my school's policies. But did you make it back? Was it all cool in the end? Not really even worked up about either of those things. Just figure there needs to be room for discussion.

I like how accounting is all about details and making sure everything adds up perfectly. With finance, I enjoy the bigger picture stuff, like planning and managing money to grow wealth. Both have their perks, which makes it tough to choose.

Both accounting and finance offer unique rewards, and it's understandable that having to choose feels challenging. You enjoy the precision and detail in accounting, while finance appeals to your interest in strategic planning and wealth management. Can you share more about any experiences or moments that have stood out to you in either field?

concern:
title: Choosing between jobs that are better financially and one’s that add to your resume
This decision has been bothering me for the past couple of days. I’m a computer science major who is studying for my masters (am a freshman atm) but choosing where to work during the school year isn’t exactly as easy as your summer job, obviously. My school has an IT department that students can work for that seems like pretty great experience and allows a little bump to my resume when I am to apply for internships in the tech field. 

On the other hand though, you have jobs like Doordash that allow more flexibility in your schedule (which would be extremely helpful) and just pay significantly more. I’m not just referring to Doordash but many jobs in the area. This is not a straightforward do this or do that question of course, but I’m just stuck at a cross roads and am having a hard time choosing. Anyone got any pointers on what I should choose here? This isn’t going to be a full commitment, I hope to get an internship instead as I progress through college, but the choice still matters, thanks so much for the help in advance.

concern:
title: Too stupid for college?
Hi, so honestly I never thought i would go to college but here i am and my first class is tomorrow. I was homeschooled all through out high school, which wasn’t the best for me and honestly I didn’t learn much. On top of that, my ADHD and depression have given me severe memory loss, so i don’t remember much that i did learn. I’m horrible at simple math, i still have to count on my fingers, and i have trouble spelling and sounding words out. I’m just really scared i’m going to look like a dumbass and it makes me not want to go. I was picked on in middle school for having learning troubles and i’m worried it’s going to be the same. That my professors or the students will think i’m stupid. What if they call on me during lecture and i don’t know the answer then everyone thinks i’m dumb lol. Please help, my anxiety is so bad i want to skip my first day.

concern:
title: Do I bother trying to find research my final semester of college?
I’m a dual degree student graduating in May. Due to COVID (yes, we’ve all heard it before) and overcoming some personal struggles, I have yet to work in a campus research lab. I did email some professors over the years, but they either didn’t respond or couldn’t take me on. Now that I’m in my last semester, do I bother trying to get into a research lab or let the subject go? 

I did complete a research internship this past summer and have a research assistant position in the same lab lined up for after graduation in order to prepare for graduate school in a couple years. Many professors won’t take on seniors because they can’t commit long to a project. To be honest, I’m not sure I want to put myself through the stress of finding a lab again, but I feel like a failure for not having participated in research at my school like many of my peers. Any advice?

concern:
title: i’ve been skipping classes and putting little to no effort into assignments and idk how to get outa the hole im in
i need advice 

i’m a college freshman in my second semester and i haven’t had any motivation to get any of my work done for my college courses. in highschool i was on top of my stuff all the time and looking back i don’t know how i managed to work part time and take 7 classes. I’m only taking 4 classes (16 credits) and i feel so unmotivated and overwhelmed.  my earliest class is at 11am and i can’t get myself up out of bed to go every morning. i don’t know what to do or how to get out of the funk i’m in. 

One of my college professors emailed me saying that I need to be more active and participate in class because my grade is low. The course material have the time is completely difficult for me to understand and I always attend office hours to try and get more help but I just can’t seem to graph the concept sometimes. it just makes me feel guilty and then when I do attend class I feel like I’m the only person that’s not understanding what’s being taught.  I had to drop one my labs the semester because I didn’t have the time and I stopped putting in the effort to try and get all of the work done. I was putting in about three hours of prep work for a class that I only had once a week, which I think is absolutely ridiculous. The lecture for that class takes about nine hours of work outside of the lectures. 

at this point I just have no idea what to do and how to get out of this hole that I’m in


TLDR , I’ve been procrastinating course work and have had little motivation when it comes to school and I don’t know what to do.

concern:
title: Teaching Art?

I’m considering going back to school to become an art teacher because I have been doing a part time art teaching job right now and I’m enjoying it a lot. I want more opportunities in this field because art is my true passion. I have two big worries though. One thing I worry about is taking on even more debt since I have so much and the other thing I worry about is the fact that it’s entirely possible that I could end up still struggling to hold down a job due to mental health stuff.

I’d love to hear some input from you guys about what I should do since it’s a big decision.

concern:
title: Repercussions to quitting internship early
I’m currently doing a remote international internship with a startup company (i’m a rising junior). My contract technically states I end on September 30th as I entered it in April, BUT my boss had made it clear she wanted me to work for 6 months via email (so around end of November as I actually started doing work in May).

I feel like I’m in way over my head and that I won’t have time to do an internship alongside my studies once college starts. I want to quit by September 30th but am scared as to what she would say/what would happen if I don’t stick it out for 6 months (I’ve been working for ~2 months now and quitting in September would make it a total of 4 months).

I’m debating talking to her about it but don’t know what to say. Will there be any repercussions if I end this internship on a bad note? Any tips or advice would be much appreciated!

concern:
title: Master's Program Decision Advice Needed
I'm a prospective master's student that applied to higher education programs. I got into both my top schools and my safety school (yay!!), but the top schools didn't offer me much in terms of scholarships. I just got an assistantship for my safety school that would cover pretty much everything, along with a stipend for living expenses. The issue is that the safety school isn't as good of a fit as the other schools in terms of my academic interests and career goals. I also don't have any loans from undergraduate, so I am okay with taking out loans for graduate school. Another factor is the safety school is my current undergraduate institution, so I wouldn't have to move unless I wanted to be closer to the school, whereas the other schools are either across the state or out of state. 

Should I take the full ride even though I'm not totally in love with the program? Or should I take out loans to go to a program that perfectly aligns with my goals? What helped you pick a program?

concern:
title: after getting through school with increasingly worst habits, I have officially failed an entire semester.
I should've known it was coming. I am so stuck, and beyond knowing what to do. 

Since the second semester of 10th grade, I have been depressed. I had spent about a year and a half obsessed with overachieving, eager to perform well, terrified of not living up to my father's expectations - and it had led me to a bunch of self-destructive study habits, that I didn't realize was harmful because it worked. Because I was GOOD at school, I was great at drawing, I was great at essays, I was lazy, but still determined and managed to get around to getting what I wanted out of myself. This is starting to sound like a very typical 'gifted' kid situation. But I really was good at a lot of things.

I have this vivid memory of the first time I realized my body was *tired*. I had a deadline coming up for one of my classes, it was the night before, and I remember sitting in my chair, realizing that I wasn't stressed. That last-minute surge of energy I used to get hours before a deadline, that stress that I used to rely on, it didn't come. It was only after the deadline had passed, that my body sprang into action.

But I was lucky back then. The tenth grade and the years following. Granted countless extensions, had understanding and generous teachers - and at the end of the day, even if it was as if I had no stress or motivation left in my body, I would still get it done at some point. I didn't realize though, that even though I got through those assignments, it had made me insanely ashamed. I spent my eleventh grade suicidal because of how much I hated my brain for not working normally, for not being the way it used to be. I would have breakdowns every night before a deadline.

With every semester, it had gotten worse - I almost didn't graduate high school because I had waited till the day before the very last day of an online class to do an entire course's work.

Then when I got to university, I barely scraped by. My first year had earned me a warning about my gpa. And I'd been so determined to do better. So determined to change - I've always been. The pandemic had torn my mental health apart - but it was okay, because now my classes were going to be in person, there was no excuse to not do well.

For the first time, this year, during the first semester of my second year of university, I failed every single class I attended.

37 minutes ago was my final extended deadline to hand in a term paper. I am majoring in something I love, in something I'm privileged to be able to study.

But I stood there in front of a blank screen and did everything I could to distract myself from working. Going on my phone, scrolling through Twitter, playing games, apartment hunting, daydreaming while I listen to music, getting up to make food. Anything to keep myself from feeling any dread, and that would enable me to stay comfortable in my little bubble of self-hate and procrastination.

It's as if my brain cannot fathom putting in effort into *anything* anymore. I'd like to take a moment that this burnout has impacted all areas of my life. I don't draw. I don't write. I can hardly muster up the strength to write emails. I want so much for myself but it's as if this parasite in my brain manages to manipulate me into doing absolutely nothing. And now I've thrown away four months of dragging my feet through courses for nothing.

I don't know how to change. I love studying literature, and I love the idea of school, but what's the point if I barely put effort into it? If I'm wracking up student debt just to fail? Just to throw it all away.

I don't even know what to do. I'm afraid to tell my mother. She'll be so devastated, and she'll just blame herself. 

I don't even know the point of living if I'm just going to be on autopilot my whole life. If I'm just going to dream about reaching my goals, and never actually put the work to it.

I wasn't even spoiled growing up. I was raised by a strong single mother that did everything to make sure I could have a life that I flourish in - but all I do is disappoint her. And my father. 

I'm sorry this was really long, but I can't talk to anyone about it and needed to just get it out there.

dialogue.statement: Hi there! What brings you in today? Feel free to share whatever's on your mind.
client: Hey! I've just been really stressed about my major and what I should do for a career. I'm feeling unsure if I'm on the right path with my art degree.
It can be really overwhelming to feel uncertain about such important decisions like your major and career path. What is it about your art degree that's making you question if it's right for you?

client: I guess I'm just worried that it won't lead to a stable job, and I don't feel super confident in my ability to market myself as an artist. Plus, I've been thinking a lot about wanting to help people in a more direct way.

You have a lot on your plate with concerns about job stability and self-marketing as an artist, and you're also drawn to helping people directly. What's been your experience with combining your interest in art with your desire to help others?
client: I've thought about art therapy, but I'm not sure if that's the right fit for me. I don't really know how to start or if it's even a viable option.

statement.reasoning: The client has shared concerns about their career path, combining art and helping others, and potential barriers. They have expressed feelings, thoughts, and context. Rapport seems established with mutual understanding of their struggles. The conversation reflects a readiness to explore motivations for change and address uncertainties.

dialogue.statement: Exploring options like art therapy can be both exciting and daunting. It's understandable to feel unsure about where to begin or if it's the right path. How does the idea of art therapy align with your values and what you hope to achieve in your career?

concern:
title: Stuck on a major early in college.
Hello everyone, sorry for the vague title. Currently I'm in my third quarter of my first year (technically second because I had to withdraw for mental health reasons but I'm going back). My current plan is getting an AA in Fine Art. I know, it's basically a joke degree but I'm an artist at a fairly respectable community college. (SPSCC if anyone cares.)

Anyway, my issue is that I struggled for years to be a freelance artist but now I have mental health fixed, I'm wondering if I should try something more rigorous or dependable for a degree. I've been told I should try for an occupational therapist career because I've seen what they do now in person and it seems like a good job where I can actually help people. 

I really want my skills to be useful and helpful, because I am so unconfident in my ability to start a business and market myself. Another barrier to traditional employment is that I have face tattoos. Is there any way I can make this art degree into a "proper" career or should I keep trying to be a professional artist? Any advice will help. If I can't succeed as an artist I'd like to get into the medical field but I'm afraid nobody will want me. Thank you for reading ❤️

dialogue.statement: Hello there! How are you doing today? Feel free to share anything that's on your mind.

Well, it's just that the workload feels never-ending, and it's like I'm constantly playing catch-up. Plus, I have to juggle it with other classes and work, so it's just a lot on my plate.

Managing so many responsibilities can certainly feel overwhelming. You're feeling this way because the constant need to catch up with your Aleks course, alongside other classes and work, is really heavy right now. Would you like to tell me more about how you've been managing all these commitments so far?

The client shared their strategy and the cycle of stress they experience. Empathy and rapport appear to be established through reflective listening.

It sounds like you have some thoughtful ideas on how to create more balance. What would it feel like to reach out to your professor or establish those boundaries for yourself?

client(guiding): I think reaching out to my professor would feel a bit intimidating, but it could be worth it if it helps reduce the stress. Setting boundaries for myself seems necessary, but I worry about sticking to them when there's always so much to do.

concern:
title: Anyone using Aleks math? What are your thoughts on it? (Story)
The concept makes sense, but it is repetitive. All three of my math professors have used aleks due to blended classes. So students Aleks are different from each other. This professor was more annoying due to her giving us so much damn work, I was doing more math than any of my other class work for other classes. My professor once thought it was a good idea to give us 74 topics once, but in a span of two weeks so there was sometime to it. I lost my mind and got up to 53. I ended up passing the class. 

The second one, I did fine in the first half and the topics were a lot less compared to the first class, but I started to be in a deep burnout state and even getting COVID that I gave up and failed the class due to constantly completing Aleks and just saying fuck all to any topics and assignments.

Now my third professor and I’m making up the class. I’ve somewhat came up with a better system to complete them: on average, it’s 24 topics due in a span of 3-4 days. Of those three days, I complete six topics a day. I’m still in that system. Slipped a bit because I have to put my attention to two other classes and somewhat procrastinated. But now I’ve realized I’ve put so much time in Aleks, I’m somewhat behind in other classes. And I wanted to try and enjoy my weekend whilst maintaining Aleks and I’m seeing a module that is due March 5 of next month that I haven’t touched due to me working on the current module (which I have 33 topics remaining out of 140 I think so I’ve been doing good). 

And I have to work this weekend, but it looks like I may have to call out both days to maintain Aleks and other class work. Which is already bad because I haven’t been working as much recently. 

So now I’m just frustrated and confused on my options because Aleks is taking up too much of my time). And I’m not kidding when I say I have had full on panic attacks due to trying to complete Aleks to pass the class with a C or above. Anyone else?

dialogue.statement: Hello! It's great to have you here. What would you like to talk about today?

Hey, thanks for having me. I've been feeling a bit unsure about choosing my major, especially since computer science wasn't the right fit for me. I'm leaning towards business administration but I've heard mixed reviews, and I'm also considering minors in French and Psychology. I'm just not sure if it's the right path or if it'll be too difficult.

It sounds like you're weighing a lot of options and feeling a bit uncertain about your next steps. What is it about business administration that draws your interest, and how do you feel about potentially taking on minors in French and Psychology?

client: Well, business administration seems practical, like it could open up a lot of job opportunities in the future. As for the minors, French seems useful because of its relevance here in Canada, and Psychology just sounds interesting to me. I'm just worried if I'm setting myself up for something too challenging.

It seems like you're drawn to business administration for its practicality and potential career benefits, while French and Psychology offer personal interest and relevance. Feeling worried about the challenge is understandable. What aspects of these subjects excite you or concern you the most?

I'm excited about the idea of understanding how businesses work and maybe getting into management or something like that. French is appealing because it could make me more marketable in Canada, and I just find Psychology fascinating—like understanding how people think and behave. But I'm concerned about whether I'll be able to keep up with the coursework, especially if business classes require a B- or better.

statement.reasoning: The client has expressed their concerns about choosing a major and minors, highlighting the perceived benefits and potential challenges. The client's thoughts and feelings have been clearly articulated, and mutual understanding has been established. We can now transition to guiding the client to explore their motivations and potential changes.

It's insightful that you're recognizing both your motivation and your concerns. What might help you shift that confidence from a 5 or 6 to a higher number?

client(guiding): I guess having a better idea of what to expect from the classes would help, like knowing the workload or the types of assignments. Maybe talking to professors or students who are already in the major could give me a clearer picture. Also, finding good study strategies or time management tips might boost my confidence.

Maybe I'll keep track by jotting down what I learn from these conversations and any strategies I pick up. That way, I can see how I'm progressing and what else I need to do.

The client has expressed commitment by setting a timeline and seeking accountability. They are also open to follow-ups for further support. These elements indicate readiness to move forward.

dialogue.statement: Looking forward to our follow-up. You've set a robust plan in motion with reaching out by Wednesday and gathering insights that will surely guide you. Identifying friends or mentors for that extra layer of support is such a great idea too. Remember, every step you take is progress, and you're doing an excellent job by taking these proactive steps. Until we check in, keep tracking your achievements and recognize your efforts—you've got this!
Thanks, I appreciate the support and encouragement. I'll keep you posted on how things go and make sure to reach out if I need any advice. Looking forward to our next session!

concern:
title: Should I Major in business administration ( B.A)
Hey everyone, 

I am a first-year student at a university and I am still not sure what major should I select I tried Computer science but it was way too hard for me, and of the other majors  Business administration stood out to me as something useful, but I have read on Reddit and other forums by some people that it is not very good of a major, I am thinking of doing a minor in French ( French is an official language here in Canada so this is something that is pretty useful to study here )  and Psychology ( minor ) to go with it? I appreciate your answers and am sorry for any typos or mistakes English is not my first language.

&#x200B;

Thanks.

I guess it makes me feel a bit left out or like I didn't fully live my teenage years. It sometimes brings up feelings of regret or worry that I might not be as prepared for adult life.

concern:
title: Did I waste my teen years?
I turn 20 tomorrow and I’ve been thinking back and reflecting on my life as a teenager and there really isn’t much there. I feel like I didn’t do the things that you’re supposed to do as a teenager. I’ve never been to a party, I don’t drink or smoke and never have, I’ve never been in a relationship or even been on a date. I spent most of my time in high school at home and same with the first year of college since it was online. I have a group of 6 close friends but now that we’re all in college we aren’t talking much. I just feel like I’ve missed out on some of the experiences people generally have growing up.

concern:
title: How do I stop stressing over a bad grade on a paper?
I made a stupid mistake. I had to miss 2 weeks of my English class because of a really terrible family issue. I stayed kept up on my work, and wrote what I thought was a very terrific paper. Unbeknownst to me, I didn’t fully read the rubric and I didn’t include some necessary information. I received a 50 on the paper, with my professor saying I had a fantastic prose but I was just missing content. I have the opportunity to COMPLETELY redo the paper at the end of the semester, yet seeing that F in the gradebook just makes my stomach turn. I’m stressed for absolutely no reason but I can’t stop. I keep worrying I’ll mess up the redo, or I’ll mess up my next papers. It makes me so scared because I’m normally a fantastic english student. I no longer feel confident in my work. How can I put myself in perspective here?

I don't want to interpret the stats, I don't care about the results, just hearing the project topic makes me want to take my laptop and smash it into little tiny pieces.

concern:
title: Should I major in Philosophy, sociology, or anthropology? will either three be a good career major?
TL;DR: I absolutely enjoy commentary and video analysis essyas that delve into the behavior of people, what they've done, and why it happened/the concerns of it. Not in a psychology way however. I'm unsure what degree best fits my desires in discussing these topics and interacting with others. However, the catch is that I also like discussions and analysis in things that aren't related to collective people, but maybe something about dreams for instance, unless it still connects to people. 



I have quite some time to pick a major as I'm in 11th grade, however I believe I mad some changes in what I degree I wanted to pursue. I originally wanted to major in communications and minor in journalism, but I noticed how I have a keen taste for commentary and analysis essays in regards to concerning phenomenons that take place omg societies. For example, I watched a video on collective trauma as a generation and how that plays out, and how the video mentioned the "spectacle" in which people are more focused on what could conform to it (such as wanting representation in the media more than being focused on what could help with agriculture in the world). The person in the video said this, but I started to realize how often this takes place now. (I'll love to go into more detail, but I get carried away with writing lol) Anyways, it made me begin to rethink what I want to pursue as a degree, and what could compliment me the most. I enjoy asking questions and socializing, however I love analysis and understanding topics in regards to how people function based on what the topic is. Carl Jung deeply interested me because of my favorite boy band implementing ideologies into their music. Which led to me question if his takes are sociology, or philosophy. I want to intergrate either one with communications, as I aspire to be a journalist; or something similar to one. I know what I'm seeking out in a degree, but not sure what degree has what I'm looking for in the future. I'm intrigued by Carl Jung's theories on dreams as well, but not sure if that's sociology or philosophy either. I like watching those videos, or see something online that could seek to be controversial or a touchy opinion, and begin to ask peers, family, or others online what their stance is on it and why. Why do people have the tendency to gravitate to someone harmful for them? Why is it hard to understand how dreams work? The relations in the subconscious and unconscious? How does this affect the functionality of people? Etc. I want to turn it into a career path, something to pursue. But I don't know what name to put to it. I mad an essay on why is it hard to be ethical online too. I can't just simply tell if sociology or philosophy is the name, or if they go hand in hand. Heck, if I can do both in college whole still minoring in communications. I'm unsure if either will be able to help me have a stable career future as well.

[What best explains the type of videos I watch](https://youtu.be/jlIBGl5-j_4)

concern:
title: Would starting therapy when I start grad school be a bad idea?
For context, I'm joining my top choice this Fall (in the US). For the last year or so, I've been really feeling that I need to go to therapy. I have an extremely low self esteem, social anxiety and I've just been stressed over the smallest of things which manifests itself as irritation and general unpleasantness. The reason I haven't gone yet is that I live at home and I share my room with a younger sibling. There's no way for me to get privacy without asking for it and I don't want my parents to know about this. My mom kinda understands but my dad doesn't really get it and has been very apprehensive. I know that if I insist, he won't stop me but I don't want to have to deal with the awkwardness considering that they would know everytime I go for a session since I'd have to kick my younger sibling out of the room. I'd rather do it privately and handle this on my own before involving my parents. 

I've been at home since the pandemic began and I've been itching to move out which is why I'm very grateful for grad school. I'd like to start therapy as soon as possible since I worry about my ability to function as an adult in a new setting when I'm struggling with every human interaction. My only concern is that I'm sure therapy will be taxing (mentally and emotionally) and grad school will be taxing in so many ways. Would it be a good idea to do start both at the same time or should I wait some more? Are my assumptions that therapy would be too distracting correct?

Well, my grades have been a big stressor. I keep falling short of where I want to be and it's just really discouraging. Plus, classes aren't exactly keeping my attention, especially with everything online.

client(exploring): I'm mostly just pushing through, trying to keep up with assignments and studying even though it's hard to concentrate. I also try to take breaks and do things I enjoy, but it doesn't always help with the stress.

concern:
title: Is this normal?
I literally feel depressed and tired every single semester and wonder if I have chosen the wrong major....

The grade scale is curved at my community college so that an 88%+ = A, 76%+ = B, 64%+ = C, and so on for the other two grades. I currently have a 63% in the class. I was almost on my way to reaching a B, but FAILED the mid term three weeks ago, along with more than have the class. This is the second time I almost reached a B, only to get dropped back down to a 62%. 

I can not just drop out for so many reasons. I was just wondering if it is normal to feel like this ?

Does anyone have any experience with taking classes online vs in person? I just... I can't focus on my professor, he is so boring. Ugh...

client: Honestly, it's been pretty chaotic. I just try to squeeze in study time whenever I can, but it feels like there's never enough hours in the day, especially with two jobs.

Juggling two jobs along with classes sounds really challenging. It seems like the lack of time is causing a lot of pressure for you. How do you usually decide which tasks to prioritize when you're short on time?
client: I mostly just go with whatever seems most urgent, like if there's a deadline coming up soon. But honestly, sometimes it feels impossible to figure out where to even start.

concern:
title: Studies
So I’m a sophomore at my local cc and last year with a job I did fairly well with three classes though I did fail one (the teacher seemed like a general jerk anyway) but part of it was also the fact that I couldn’t really understand the assignments and the teacher was never much help.

I’m afraid of flunking out of college and disappointing my parents

You feel a mix of excitement and nervousness about the PhD because of the deep research opportunities and the time and financial commitments involved. At the same time, the stability of staying in the industry appeals to you, though there's a concern about potential limits to your growth and learning. With the PhD, it's the idea of becoming an expert in a field I'm passionate about and possibly opening more doors in the future. For industry, it's the tangible experience and steady career progression without the years of school.

concern:
title: Debating About Getting My PhD?
I am 31 years old and graduated in 2020 with my Master's in Biochem and Molecular Bio. I've been working in the biotech industry for the past couple years. Like now, I also worked for a couple years in industry between my Bachelor's and Master's. However, I realized that in Biology you are very limited in pay, job opportunities, and growth with just a Bachelor's, which justified pursuing my master's. I do like learning and I think getting a PhD will make me a better Biologist overall, but I know I want to return to industry when finished. I also know if I went back to school it would be for cancer research or Epigenetics. However, unlike a masters program,  the 5+ years of school for a PhD vs the 5+ years of real life work experience is making this decision harder. In addition, the low stipends, PI stories (I've heard both good and bad), and when looking for jobs in the past, the experience potential and pay comparisons varies but not as much as I thought. What are your opinions on going back for a PhD? Do you feel like there are no more limitations with your PhD compared to just having a Master's? It would be great to hear both sides of the argument. Thank you!

dialogue.statement: Hello! What would you like to talk about today? I'm here to listen and support you.
Hey, thanks. I've been feeling pretty lost about my whole college situation. It's like I'm just going through the motions without any real purpose, you know?
College can feel overwhelming, especially when it seems like you're moving without direction. What do you think might be contributing to these feelings of being lost?

client: I guess it's mostly because I'm not really sure what I want to do with my life right now. I'm just kinda doing this college thing because it's what everyone expects, not because I'm passionate about it.

It sounds like you're navigating college based on expectations rather than personal passion, which might be contributing to that sense of being lost. Have there been any moments or experiences so far that have sparked an interest or curiosity in you?

Honestly, not really. I've been taking some general classes, but nothing has really stood out or caught my interest. It's all starting to feel a bit monotonous and like I'm not getting anywhere closer to figuring it all out.

There is empathy and rapport, and mutually agreed goals are emerging. Exploring goals appear met, allowing a shift to Guiding to strengthen motivation and evoke Change Talk.

concern:
title: How are you all able to manage everything you're doing? 😩
So for context, I'm not a grad student yet but I'm a senior undergrad who's taking 4 grad level courses, along with doing a research project and a TA-ship. Posting here because I think this is the same (probably still less) workload as most of you have and I genuinely don't know how to manage everything. And thinking about this is making me fearful of what's going to happen when I start grad school myself. 

Anyway, I'm a first time TA, and I started this out by being super energetic and responsive to students, and this is a class of 260 kids with 4 TA's in total for it. I'm the head TA, so along with dealing with student questions and grading and stuff, plus holding weekly office hours and practice sessions, I'm handling most of the managerial tasks along with it like maintaining data for everything along with organizing stuff and continuing to email the class about any and all updates about anything. Because of this, most students contact me when they have an issue, and obviously I'm going to respond to their emails, and I have to make sure they understand stuff, because this is a calc-1 class with a majority of non-stem students. I've even been setting up extra zoom meetings with some of them, which have ranged from anywhere between 30 minutes to 1.5 hours. 

The problem with this is. I can't find time to do anything else. I haven't been focusing on my courses at all, and I have a midterm in about 14 hours that I haven't even begun to study for. I have two more midterms in the next week, and again, no idea how I'm going to deal with them. The most I do is complete assignments, but some of them can easily take anywhere between 2 days, to a week (the latter for a very difficult pure math class). I also need to complete, or at least continue my senior year research project, but I haven't done anything with it for nearly a month now. I genuinely just can NOT find time for anything. And that's especially if I'm trying to make sure I have a good sleep schedule (nothing extreme, but at least 5-6 hours every night) along with maybe taking out an hour or two for myself in a day (which includes time taken to eat or nap mostly). 

I just genuinely need advice. How do you handle everything, alongside doing justice to each of your responsibilities and NOT overburdening yourself to the point of complete burnout? Do you set up schedules? I'm really sorry for posting here, but I have no idea where/who else to ask and I'm seriously going to end up completely incapable of doing anything if it continues like this.

client(reflecting): I'd say maybe a 4 or 5. I know having a schedule would help, but actually sticking to it is where I struggle. I get distracted or something comes up, and then it all kind of falls apart.

concern:
title: I had a miscarriage between two conferences (did not know I was pregnant until I was actively miscarrying) and have been on a mental and physical health roller-coaster the last 4 months. I feel so much better now, but want to be transparent, do I tell my PI what's going on?
First, it feels weird calling it a miscarriage because my husband and I are not trying to get pregnant, I have a hormonal arm implant (Nexplanon) and am in no way ready to start a family nor am sure that's something I will ever want.  I have told my mum, and a few close friends, but haven't really referred it as a miscarriage because that implies a loss.  I am so unbelievably relieved and can focus for the first time in over 3 months.  My doctor and my counselor are great allies and have been so supportive while pushing beyond me saying this is "just a normal grad school mental breakdown". I had an IUD before the arm implant and had not had a period in 5 years, so we never considered I could be pregnant and I assumed I had gained a little weight from stress eating.  Lo and behold, there is a 1/100 chance of getting pregnant with the Nexplanon arm implant, but most likely to be unviable and ectopic so there was a chance I needed a D&C which was very stressful and upsetting while busy with conference prep and international travel.  I am emotionally exhausted and did become heavily reliant on Zopiclone to sleep when I was having frequent anxiety attacks.  Now that I am feeling pretty emotionally good and weaning off the Zopiclone, I am not sleeping nearly as well without it, but on my way to feeling like myself again.  I'm still not 100%, and would want to acknowledge that something has been off about me if my PI does bring it up (which he has in the past when I've been noticeably down - I'm often described as an effervescent and vivacious person and have no poker face).  Also I am still mildly traumatized from seeing the...expelled tissue...and often can't shake the image from my head and that has not helped my sleeping situation.  When I write it all out, it sounds very dramatic and serious.  
   
On one hand, I am mentally at ease after months of uncontrollable crying, lack of focus, and intense, disruptive physical anxiety.  I was still able to do my project management job well but I had to make some big changes about my thesis and got kind of paralyzed in my own research. I don't want to diminish that my academic life is still really stressful: I work full-time as a project manager and my PI is also my MA supervisor so we see each other several times a week.  He knows me well. We have a good relationship and he is very supportive of me as a human, a researcher, and a professional in my field from before going back to school.  He is a very nurturing supervisor and has been supportive during other losses I have experienced in our time working closely together.  On the other hand, I don't know if it's better to leave it at "I've had an ongoing medical challenge but am feeling a lot better, looking forward to the holiday break and returning refreshed".  There is such a taboo about discussing women's reproductive health so it would be easier to talk about if it was strictly a mental health issue - it feels so heavy and complicated, especially with holiday parties and everyone asking "how are you?!?!?" when I'm not great.

Any advice or similar experiences would be greatly appreciated.  I know other women who struggle with the dichotomy of academia vs family and work-life balance.  I feel quite alone in this as many of my friends are starting to get baby fever or actively trying to get pregnant.

title: Rejection from grad school

I just graduated college and I applied to graduate school for that same program. Well, I was denied. This came as a complete shock to me, as I have never really been rejected from anything in life. I got responses like "it's competitive" or "a higher gpa is usually the case" (even though I was above average) and things like people had more research experience in their undergrad. I want to apply again. I can't change my grades but I can change my resume, educational personal statement, my writing examples and my references.

I am trying to keep an open mind but I feel defeated. I was applying for the fall now I need to wait until the spring semester and even then, I don't know if ill be accepted. I really have come at a crossroads in my life but I am taking it as an opportunity to learn. I feel pretty sad and rejected and unsure about the immediate future. concern:
title: Withdrawing vs. Failing Physics (Mechanics)
The grade scale is curved at my community college so that an 88%+ = A, 76%+ = B, 64%+ = C, and so on for the other two grades. I currently have a 63% in the class. I was almost on my way to reaching a B, but FAILED the mid term three weeks ago, along with more than have the class. This is the second time I almost reached a B, only to get dropped back down to a 62%.

I want to be an engineer, but this class is the most draining I have ever taken and my first physics course. I put in many hours of the week into other classes such as General Chemistry I (5 credits) and Calculus II (4 credits) (both which I have borderline Cs in). I dedicate mostly to physics (5 credits).

I’m sure to blame for the strenuous amount of work I attempted to do this semester, but I would like to (stereotypically) put some of it on the  professor. He assigns homework but no explanations are given when not answering the problems correctly, you lose points on your grade after a certain amount of attempts. Mid term was a disaster since we did not have enough time. He does not curve exams or quizzes.

Drop date is April 15th. Advice? Should I just stick with it and try to pull through? I just feel lost and down on myself now. Professor was pretty demeaning other day when he said if we don’t get a B or A in this course, we will really struggle in the next physics class (electricity and magnetism).

concern:
title: Can someone help me chose a grad school, the deadline for one of them is tomorrow
I’ve been fighting demons these past night trying to come to a decision. I got into these three schools for a masters in mechanical engineering with thesis option. None are offering any money or assistance, this makes sense though since  I’m coming into a spring semester. I would need to take out loans my first semester regardless of where I go and get a part time job. All locations have accommodations for a hobby I have but I would like a friend to be able to hang out with, I’m too lonely in undergrad lol.

Options and some notes: 
University of Florida- cheapest housing and some good possible opportunities for funding later down the line. Also has grad housing which is even cheaper if I manage to get one of those. I also have a chance at maybe getting a teaching position in the chem department as I teach chem at my current undergrad. Has cool labs and research in my concentration of controls and robotics.

University of central Florida- good school and a lot of jobs around the area that have benefits. I have a friend there so I’ll have someone to hangout with for about two semesters before they graduate. Cheapest tuition, housing can be as expensive as Manhattan although there can be plenty of options found.

City college of New York- very good school but they said they do not have a track record of offering assistantships for masters but almost all masters students come out nearly debt free. I’ll be able to live by my Aunty, which covers housing and food, on Long Island but the commute will be very long(~2.5 hour train ride or 1-1.5 hour drive during morning rush). I feel like the commute after working might take too much time from working on my thesis but I don’t really know how much time grad students actually have and I’m sure I’d adapt to it though. There are a lot of part time jobs in New York and CCNY federal work studies( I know other schools offer that as well).

Healthcare is also very very important since I have recently been diagnosed with a few illnesses and need insurance to afford the medicine. This makes getting a job with benefits important if I stay in Florida whereas New York i can apply for Medicaid.

I don’t know which one to choose, I like them all and each have their own cons. I also self toured all schools but it was kind of rushed since my parents was rushing to leave. 

I did apply to some scholarships and fellowships but they are for fall 23 school year. I would appreciate anyone’s help, I know it’s last minute but I just can’t make a set decision.

title: Asking for perspective (BS with concentration vs just BS General, then go for masters)

concern:
title: What should I do?
I’m a recent highschool graduate from the class of 22’ I always wanted to go to college and try to further my studies. I lost almost half my highschool education due to covid so getting back into school hasn’t been the easiest thing, in highschool I managed 90s in everything but I never had to pickup a book. My actual major starts next semester and this current semester has 9 weeks left. I’m struggling at every corner even when I apply myself and try to study the material. I want to drop out and continue my studies next semester or later on within business. But I don’t see a reason in sitting here learning material and putting in endless hours into something that provides me with almost nothing in return or the only good return being the discovery of something I hate. I go to a fairly cheap community college and financial aid eliminates about half of my overall 2 year tuition which is only 5,600 before aid. My parents keep telling me I’m just lazy, that I dont actually want to do anything except smoke weed and hang out with my girlfriend. Whenever i bring up the idea of a trade or anything else i’m immediately told i’m not cut out for it and that my best option is to sit here and suffer for the next 100 days. Every day is taking such a heavy toll on me just trying to manage to stay afloat everyday and getting through to the night is so difficult right now.
