concern:
title: Is it normal to be UNDERwhelmed first semester?
Freshman here majoring in Computer Networking. I’m finding that majoring in networking is like comp sci without the majority of programming, or cybersecurity without a lot of the math requirements that major usually requires. 

I’m afraid that i’m not spending enough time in my classes/on assignments. I’m taking 16 credits right now (four classes with two labs) and I’m underwhelmed by the workload. 

My comp sci and math classes are the only classes I really put decent time into. My english class is a composition course, and I only have essays as my grade.

I’m also taking a networking course, but I took this same course last year so I’m familiar with the material. 

Am I not spending enough time? Did I just get lucky this semester? I was told all my life that the college workload was crazy, and being done with all my weekly work by Wednesday makes me feel like I’m doing something wrong

dialogue.statement: Hello! How are you feeling today? What's on your mind?
Hey, I'm hanging in there. Just feeling overwhelmed trying to juggle work and school. It's like there's never enough time or energy to do everything I need to do.

Balancing work and school sounds really challenging. You feel overwhelmed because you're trying to manage so many responsibilities at once. Can you tell me more about how this is affecting you day-to-day?

client: Yeah, it's just hard to keep up. Most days I come home from work too tired to even start on homework, so I put it off. Then I feel stressed because I'm always playing catch-up and it feels like I'm stuck in this loop where I can't catch a break.

That sounds like a tough cycle you're experiencing—feeling too exhausted to get started and then stressed about falling behind. It seems like you're stuck in a loop of trying to catch up. How does this stress impact other areas of your life?

client: It's definitely affecting my mood. I'm more irritable and feel anxious all the time. I barely have time for friends or hobbies, and I miss those parts of my life. Everything feels out of balance.

statement.reasoning: The client's story has been well-elucidated, including thoughts and feelings of exhaustion, stress, and imbalance due to juggling work and school. Empathy and rapport are evident, and mutual understanding of the client's struggles has been reached. This suggests readiness to explore motivation and change strategies.

dialogue.statement: It must be really hard to feel like you're missing out on things that bring you joy. When you think about finding balance and managing stress, what changes do you envision could help you reconnect with what’s important to you?

client: Honestly, I just wish I had more time or energy. Maybe if I could manage my schedule better or find a way to fit in small breaks, it would help. I need to find a way to have some downtime without feeling guilty about it.
Taking small breaks without guilt could really help in restoring some balance. When you think about managing your schedule to allow for downtime, what small changes feel manageable to start with?

client(guiding): Maybe I could try setting aside specific times for breaks, like short ones during work or school days, and stick to them. Also, it might help to plan my homework in smaller chunks rather than trying to tackle it all at once.
Having dedicated break times and breaking tasks into smaller parts sounds like a smart approach. How might these changes align with your overall goals for balance and well-being?

client(guiding): I think they'd definitely help me feel less overwhelmed and more in control. If I can manage my time better, I might start feeling less stressed and anxious. Ultimately, I'd like to have more energy for things I enjoy and not feel like I'm constantly playing catch-up.

statement.reasoning: The client identified specific manageable changes, indicating a shift from exploring to action planning. Change talk is present with a clear goal to manage time better and include breaks. There's alignment with their overall goals for balance and well-being, reducing stress and enhancing energy. No sustain talk is observed, signaling readiness to move ahead.

Let's consider creating an action plan together. Would you like to set a goal for how many breaks you'd like to incorporate daily, or how you'd like to structure your homework time? client(choosing): Yeah, setting an action plan sounds like a good idea. I think aiming for at least two or three short breaks each day could be a decent start. For homework, maybe splitting it into 30-minute chunks with breaks in between could help keep me focused. As for barriers, I guess the biggest one would be sticking to the plan when I'm feeling super tired or unmotivated. Maybe having some kind of reminder or incentive could keep me on track.

Setting a goal of two or three short breaks daily and structuring homework into 30-minute chunks sounds very manageable. Using reminders or incentives could be a great way to stay motivated. Would you like to brainstorm some options for reminders or incentives that might work for you? Also, how would you like to monitor your progress and make sure this plan supports your well-being?

As for incentives, maybe treating myself to something small, like a favorite snack or a short walk outside, after completing a task might help. To monitor my progress, I could keep a journal or checklist to track how well I'm sticking to the plan and how I'm feeling overall.

Those are excellent strategies to keep yourself on track. Using a journal or checklist to track your adherence and feelings is a thoughtful way to reflect on your progress. client(choosing): I think this plan could really help bring some structure and balance back into my day. It feels good to have some concrete steps to follow rather than just feeling overwhelmed. Knowing there's a plan in place might make it easier to enjoy the little things again and not feel so drained all the time.

concern:
title: College isn't conducive to those who work full time
I work four days a week, which is full time in my state, and I go to college two days a week (two out of three of my days off). During the week, I still have homework to do, but I work all day and then come home absolutely exhausted. I have no motivation or energy to do said homework and usually wait until the day before to do everything. Taking three classes (a full time schedule) is what is needed to keep my financial aid, and while that's all well and good, I don't know how other people who work even more than I do can do this. I am at work for 8-9hrs each day, and at school for about 5.5hrs each of my two days, plus an online class. I have such a hard time doing school after work because I am so mentally checked out by that point that even getting myself to take a shower can be a struggle. And I have a hard time doing homework after I get home from school because I just spent all day at school. I'm just so over everything. I wanna go back to being five again.

dialogue.statement: Hello, how are you feeling today? What's been on your mind lately?
Hey, I'm doing okay. I've just been thinking about graduation and how I'm not really into the idea of wearing all the regalia for myself.
Graduation seems to bring up mixed feelings for you. What is it about wearing the regalia that isn't appealing to you?
client: I guess it just feels like too much attention on me, and I get a bit embarrassed by that. Plus, spending money on it seems unnecessary when I’d rather focus on other things.
It sounds like you're feeling a bit uncomfortable with being the center of attention and also concerned about the cost involved. What are some of those other things you'd prefer to focus on instead?

I think I'd rather just focus on celebrating with friends and family, maybe doing something low-key like a dinner or a hangout. Those moments seem more personal and meaningful to me than wearing special attire.

statement.reasoning: The client's story, including feelings of discomfort with attention and cost concerns, has been elicited. Rapport is established. The client has articulated a preference for personal celebrations over traditional ceremonies, indicating clear thoughts and feelings. However, exploring deeper into underlying beliefs or past experiences could further enrich understanding.

dialogue.statement: Celebrating in a way that's personal and meaningful to you is important. You prefer a more intimate setting with loved ones over the attention that comes with traditional graduation attire. How do you envision that celebration with your friends and family?

I picture it as a small gathering, maybe at a nice restaurant or someone’s house, where we can just relax, chat, and enjoy each other's company. It would be less about the formalities and more about us sharing the moment together.

statement.reasoning: The client has shared thoughts and feelings about graduation regalia, emphasizing discomfort with attention and unnecessary expenses, while expressing a preference for intimate celebrations. Empathy and rapport appear strong, with mutual understanding of the client's goals. The conversation has sufficiently covered the client's narrative, making it suitable to move to Guiding.

dialogue.statement: That sounds like a heartfelt way to celebrate, prioritizing connection over formality. How might this type of celebration align with your values and goals for this special time in your life?

I think it aligns well with my values because it's all about being genuine and focusing on the relationships that really matter. My goal is to enjoy the moment and appreciate the people who supported me through this journey, rather than getting caught up in the traditional pomp and circumstance.

Your focus on authenticity and meaningful relationships really stands out. It seems like celebrating this way helps you to truly honor those connections and your personal journey. On a scale from 0 to 10, how confident are you in making this kind of celebration happen?
client(reflecting): I’d say I’m around a 7 or 8. I feel pretty good about it, but there's still a bit of uncertainty about whether others might expect the traditional approach.

therapist(guiding): It's understandable to feel some uncertainty, especially when considering others' expectations. Yet, your 7 or 8 confidence shows you're quite determined. What might help boost your confidence and move closer to a 9 or 10?

client(reflecting): Talking to my family and friends about it would probably help, just to see if they're on board with the idea. Maybe getting their reassurance that they’re cool with a non-traditional celebration would make me feel more confident.

statement.reasoning: The client expressed a specific change goal of having a non-traditional, low-key celebration. Change Talk is present, and the client’s confidence is rated at 7-8, indicating a readiness to act. Ambivalence is acknowledged and addressed with a plan to seek reassurance from family and friends. Therefore, the client appears ready to develop specific action plans for this change.

dialogue.statement: Discussing your ideas with your family and friends seems like a great step forward. How would you like to start planning that conversation, and what might you say to them to express your feelings and hopes for this celebration?

client(reflecting): I think I'd just sit them down and be open about how I'm feeling. I'd tell them that I really value spending quality time with them and that I hope we can celebrate in a way that's meaningful for all of us, even if it's not the traditional way.

Starting that conversation openly and honestly is a wonderful approach. You might begin by sharing your feelings about the celebration and why this approach matters to you. Would you like to consider some potential responses or questions they might have, or think about how you’d like to handle any concerns they express?

client(choosing): Yeah, that would be helpful. I'm sure they'll be supportive, but they might have questions or concerns about not doing the traditional thing. It would be good to be prepared to reassure them and maybe find a compromise if needed.

therapist(choosing): Preparing for potential questions and concerns is a wise step. You could reassure them by emphasizing the value of the celebration you envision and how it reflects your shared bonds. Would you like to brainstorm some possible responses or discuss ways to find a balance between tradition and your personal preferences?

client(choosing): Yeah, brainstorming some responses would be great. I want to make sure they know I still respect the traditional aspects and understand if they have sentimental attachments to them. Finding a balance that honors both their feelings and mine would be ideal.

statement.reasoning: The client has a clear goal and action plan to discuss non-traditional celebration ideas with family and friends. They are preparing for potential barriers by brainstorming responses to questions or concerns. The client shows confidence and commitment to their plan. Hence, the Choosing phase goals are met, and it's appropriate to advance to Terminating.

dialogue.statement: That's a thoughtful approach, ensuring everyone feels valued in the process. You might express your respect for tradition by acknowledging its importance to them and suggesting ways to incorporate meaningful elements. For example, you could say, "While I’d like to celebrate in a way that feels genuine to me, I’m open to including certain traditions that hold special meaning for you." This could help in finding a middle ground. As you prepare for this conversation, consider reflecting on any specific traditions that might blend well with your idea. This could serve as a bridge, showcasing your willingness to create a celebration that honors both perspectives. As you move forward, remember that your openness and willingness to engage are key strengths here. Keep those in mind as your guide.
Thanks for the suggestions. I'll definitely keep that in mind as I plan how to talk to them. It feels good to have a way to balance things out and make sure everyone feels included.

statement.reasoning: The client and therapist summarized goals and coping strategies, discussed steps for conversations with family, and developed a next-step plan for balancing traditions and personal preferences, achieving closure naturally.

concern:
title: Does anyone else not like the idea of graduation regalia for themselves?
Maybe it's just me, but I don't see the point in spending money on a stole, cords, medallion, or a special tassel just to show off academic accomplishments. I feel embarrassed when they're pointed out, anyway, so I can't imagine willingly wearing that stuff to draw attention to myself.

The weird thing is, I only feel this way when it comes to myself. Seeing other people in their regalia makes me happy and proud of them, so why can't I feel that way for myself?

Hey, thanks for seeing me. I've just been really worried about starting at this new school and whether I'll be able to keep up academically. It's been kinda stressing me out.
Starting at a new school can indeed bring a lot of concerns. You're feeling stressed because you're unsure about keeping up with the academic demands, right?

Yeah, exactly. I mean, coming from a less competitive high school, I'm just worried I might fall behind everyone else who's had a stronger academic background. It's just been weighing on me, you know?

It sounds like you're carrying the weight of uncertainty about how you'll fit in academically with your new peers. Coming from a different high school environment, it's understandable to feel concerned about this transition. What has your experience been like in similar situations before?

client (exploring): Well, in the past, I've always managed to catch up, but it took a lot of effort and late nights. It's just that this time it feels like the stakes are way higher, and I'm worried that might not be enough.

concern:
title: Paranoid and Concerned Low Income Student
Okay so I’m a low income student and I’ve recently been admitted to an Ivy on a really big scholarship (basically full ride) and I’ve been having concern about my academic performance. My school is a pretty non-competitive school and most of the curriculum we’re taught is pretty much dumbed down to ensure everyone passes and graduates. I’m scared that I won’t be able to handle the curriculum thrown at me at an Ivy because I didn’t have a good foundation from my high school compared to other students. So my questions are: 

1. Are remedial courses included in my scholarship? If I have to take a remedial math course but I can’t afford then what 🥲🥲😳😳😳
2. Are there free college courses anywhere I can take over the summer to supplement my learning? I was thinking about my local community college but I don’t to spend too much since I’m kinda broke😅

Pls help

dialogue.statement: Hello there! I’m here to listen and support you. What's on your mind today?

You're drawn to the challenging and complex aspects of medical work, which seems to be creating some uncertainty about your current path. What do you think makes these intense situations so appealing to you?
I guess it's the adrenaline and the challenge of it all. It's like solving a puzzle and requires quick thinking, which I find exciting and rewarding.

The excitement and sense of accomplishment you feel from solving those complex "puzzles" really stand out to you. What aspects of your current studies do you think align or conflict with those feelings?

client(exploring): I mean, studying to be a vet does line up because there are definitely intense cases, but sometimes it's more routine than I expected. I'm just wondering if there's something else out there that hits that sweet spot more consistently.

It's the regular check-ups and the day-to-day stuff that feels a bit too predictable. I was hoping for more of those intense cases, but they don't come as often as I thought they would.

concern:
title: what majors can lead you to deal with medical/gore?
After working at a pet ER I realized I find "gore" fascinating. I like to see the more messed up or nasty cases and I wonder, What majors is there that deal with such things besides a veterinarian and doctor? I'm studying to be a vet because I love animals first but the bloody stuff seems really cool.

 I know police officers may stumble upon dead bodies/murders which is one thing and I know doctors (or vets) see medical type gore but I wonder what other jobs deal with such? It can deal with law enforcement or medical field, I just want to know besides the common typical jobs/majors.

concern:
title: Can’t afford this year and it’s making me so depressed 
I had a scholarship last year so I knew this was coming but had hoped I’ll find a solution. I applied to so many teaching positions but none led to anything. Except for one professor that hired me but because her class got low enrollment it was downgraded to a grader position so I don’t get the tuition waiver. I’ve applied to a few scholarships but decisions won’t come until later in the semester. I’m not sure if I should just continue with the semester hoping for things to get better. Going to class everyday feels like a chore. I feel like an imposter and wonder if I should be here. I’m considering taking a semester off but I was advised to just take the entire year off due to the nature of my program. I’m so happy to see all my friends and thinking I probably won’t be with them for the year hurts me. I’ve been applying to jobs as plan b but even that hasn’t bored any fruits. I’m so scared yall. Just needed to rant

concern:
title: Stage fright while teaching??
So I TAed for the first time today and oh my god - I was not prepared for the absolute panic mode my body would go into. I was shaking, voice was shaking, watery eyes, short of breath, nauseous, the whole 9 yards. I spit out a presentation in 3 minutes because I was talking so fast. I’ve been known to get nervous for presentations but never have I ever had such a reaction. Maybe I’m overthinking it but I’m pretty sure everyone could tell how nervous I was too, which just makes it worse. 
How do you guys cope? Does it get better? How does it get better? I’m hoping that as I do it more, my body will settle down but for now I really need advice.

concern:
title: Years and years of school feels like a waste of my youth
I’m 24 year old female. I took a while to do 75 credits of college plus did a 9 month “lds” mission (ew) and took a year off. 

as a philosophy major I’ll graduate and do more schooling. I knew that when I was younger going into it. Now? … I feel like my most reproductive, pretty years of my life will go to finding a way to support myself financially.

dialogue.statement: Hi there! What would you like to talk about today? Feel free to share what's on your mind.
Hey. I've been stressing over how to talk to my family about leaving college. I dropped out and now I'm just stuck on whether I should tell them before Christmas or let them find out on their own.

That's a tough spot to be in, with a lot of emotions swirling around. It must feel overwhelming, weighing the decision of when and how to share this news with your family. What has been your main concern about approaching this topic with them?

client: Yeah, it's definitely overwhelming. My main concern is how disappointed they'll be, especially since they were helping me financially. I'm worried about how they'll react and how it might affect our relationship.

It makes sense to be worried about their reaction and the impact on your relationship, particularly when they've been supporting you financially. You're feeling anxious about disappointing them because your relationship is important to you. What have you thought about when it comes to how you might approach this conversation with them?

I've thought about being honest and just explaining why college wasn't for me and what I'm planning to do instead. I want them to see that I have a plan and that I'm committed to making it work, but I'm just unsure how they'll take it.

concern:
title: Tell my family now or let them find out I dropped out
I went to college for a month, then dropped out because I didn't like it at all and I wasn't feeling good in there at all. I decided to pursue an artistic career (not requiring a degree) in parallel of a job. It's what I always wanted to do and I tried to tell them so many times, but they wouldn't understand. So I decided to not ask them this time and I just dropped out. Now it's the end of semester and soon they'll find out, it could even be before christmas, but should I tell them anyways before Christmas though ? I just don't feel like keep lying to them and receive all of my gifts for my "hard work" that I didn't even do. The problem is also that they were paying for my rent and helping me financially, so without their help I'm in a complicated situation although I can still find a job easily, since I have some experience.

concern:
title: super burnt out, but i feel guilty about taking the summer off
hey guys, so i graduate next weekend from my undergrad and as I'm finishing up my finals I'm facing a huge dilemma. This year has been particularly difficult in terms of coursework as I've been writing my thesis, but I've also had a lot going on with my campus job (i work in an office) as someone else quit and left me and one other person with their huge list of responsibilities that has taken up a lot of my time. I feel so miserably burnt out trying to get through the rest of this semester and the idea of applying and interviewing to get a temporary summer job before I start grad school in August sounds like a nightmare. I would love to use this summer as a break before my rigorous grad program that runs all year long for about 3 years, but I also feel guilty about the idea of not having a summer job (I'd get an internship but jfc there are none in my area that will allow anyone who isn't already a grad student in, plus my program will put me into an intership position anyways). My family keeps telling me that they're glad I'll finally have a break but I'm worried about being dead weight, have any of you been in this position before? Am I being overdramatic in one way or another? This might just be the finals stress rotting my brain but I really can't stop worrying about it. Any advice is appreciated :)

concern:
title: Graduate Community College in Fall 2022 or Spring 2023
Ok this one's a hard decision. I need 17 more credits to graduate with my 2-year degree before I go on for a bachelor's in either Journalism or Communications. I love the community college i'm in and i've made incredible friends which many will still be around with next year plus i'm still very young at 19 and want to enjoy every moment of my youth in college but at the same time, I want to go to a college in NYC and most of those who graduated with me in high school in 2020 and went to a 2-year college would be in their transfer year before graduating. In order to graduate in the fall, I need to take 6 classes to get the credits I need. I can do that, finish up faster, and get to NYC where I want to be for my last 2 years of school or take 4 and then stay another semester, take 4 (while taking advantage of financial aid) and graduate while having more personal time and less stress from classes and still make it to NYC in Fall 2023. Help me on which would be best pls.

concern:
title: Double major or change major
I am a history major and love it but have since added accounting as a second major. I am wondering should I keep the single major of accounting or get rid of history and keep it as a minor or get rid of it all together and keep the accounting major?

dialogue.statement: Hello! How are you feeling today? What's been on your mind lately?
Hey, I'm feeling pretty overwhelmed, honestly. There's just so much going on with school and I can't seem to catch a break. It's like I'm constantly running on empty.

client: It's mostly the workload. I have assignments due every day and barely any time for myself. Even when I try to catch up, it feels like I'm just getting buried deeper.

That sounds incredibly challenging, trying to keep up with the workload while it keeps piling up. You might be feeling stressed because it's hard to find time to recharge. Can you tell me more about how you try to manage everything, and if there are moments when you do find relief?

client: I try my best to stay organized, using planners and setting deadlines for myself, but it's hard to stick to them when the work just keeps coming. The only relief I get is when I manage to finish something and have a brief moment to just breathe, but it's always short-lived because there's always something else waiting.

statement.reasoning: The client has shared a detailed account of feeling overwhelmed due to an excessive workload at college. They've expressed emotions, thoughts, and context about their struggle to balance academic demands with personal well-being. The therapist has built rapport and shown empathy. I value learning and creativity, and those moments would help me reconnect with that part of myself instead of just seeing school as a never-ending grind.

Reconnecting with the joy of learning and creativity sounds enriching. How might aligning with these values change your experience at school, and what small steps could you start considering to invite more of those moments into your day?

client(guiding): If I could bring back the joy and creativity, it might make the workload feel a bit more manageable or at least more worthwhile. Maybe I could start by setting aside even a tiny block of time each day to do something creative, like a quick sketch or some free writing. Just something to remind myself why I'm here in the first place.

They identified a specific goal of integrating small creative activities into their routine, which aligns with their values. concern:
title: Overwhelmed
I (19TM) am currently in my sophomore year of college. I just started the fall semester and I'm drowning.

Last year I had a decent amount of homework but I never had trouble getting it turned in on time. And I had plenty of time to see my friends, relax, eat, and work on personal projects that interest me. This semester has been different. I have 3+ assignments due every single day, I'm in two art studios that are only worth three credits each, but you have to be in for six hours every week. I've had assignments I had to turn in incomplete because I ran out of time. And it's not for lack of trying, I'm doing homework literally every free second I get between class, meals, and sleep. I don't get enough sleep, I don't eat enough, and I have exactly zero time for personal creative endeavors.

I'm exhausted all the time, I have days where my anxiety gets so bad I burst into tears just from stress, and yet I haven't been able to slow down even a bit. It's this, or drop out. The only way out is through.

I'm writing this post as I wait for my computer to update so that I can finish a writing assignment and a quiz that are both due tonight, and I have some art project stuff that's due in class tomorrow, which means it needs to get done tonight. I'll probably be up late trying to finish it which means I won't get enough sleep again. Tomorrow evening I need to start working on an essay that's due Friday (it's currently Wednesday), and I also have a workbook page due that day. And it doesn't get any better after that. Every class has loaded me down with more assignments than is even remotely reasonable, and I'm only taking four classes because I had to drop one. I was originally taking five, but it quickly became apparent it literally was not going to be possible to complete all five of them and balance all the work. But I'm starting to get worried even four is going to be too much with the ungodly amount of work these professors assign. My dishes have piled high, my laundry has been sitting in my corner unfolded for days, I desperately need a shower, and I have online job training I need to complete at some point. I haven't had even a second to spare for any of it because every second has been dedicated to homework. If I do get a second to breath, I'm so desperate to finally relax and get even a moment to not be working that I cannot summon the will to do chores.

I know that the way I'm living right now is not healthy, but what's the alternative? Stop turning in assignments and fail my classes? Drop out of school? Neither of those are possible for me. As stressful as it is, I love school and one hard semester would never be enough to make me accept failure.

You might suggest I drop another class, but that's not an option either. If I go down to three classes I'll become a part-time student which means I would lose my scholarship. And I can't afford college without it.

There's really not much I can do other than tough it out, I just desperately needed to complain about my situation somewhere. It's been weighing on me for awhile. I would go to therapy, but I don't have time. I've had to postpone doctor's appointments of all kinds, I haven't been able to hangout with friends unless it's study session, and I haven't been able to work on my book that I'm writing or make any new art without sacrificing homework time that invariably ends up hitting my grade in that class. It's currently week 6 of 16 at my university, plus finals week. So I'm not even halfway done and I'm already crippled by how much work I have, and it's not going to slow down anytime soon.

This just really, truly sucks.

dialogue.statement: Hello, how are you feeling today? What's been on your mind lately?
I'm feeling pretty overwhelmed to be honest. I've been thinking a lot about whether I should drop out of college or try to stick it out, and it's stressing me out.

That's a lot to carry on your shoulders. You're feeling overwhelmed because you're trying to decide whether staying in college is right for you. What aspects of college are contributing to this stress?

client(exploring): Well, I think it's the pressure from my family and the uncertainty about what I actually want to study. Plus, I didn't even really want to go in the first place, so it's hard to feel motivated.

It sounds like you're juggling family expectations and your own uncertainties about your future, which makes it tough to find motivation. Can you share more about how you ended up in this situation and what your journey has been like so far?

I kind of got pushed into it by my grandmother filling out an application for me without really asking if it's what I wanted. I thought my family had all agreed it was necessary, but turns out they hadn't, so now I'm here trying to figure out if I should stick with it or just back out and take some time to think.

statement.reasoning: The client has shared a detailed account of their situation, emotions, and the context behind their current dilemma. Rapport is evident, and the therapist has shown understanding and empathy. The client's goals and challenges are clear, making it appropriate to move to the Guiding phase to explore motivation and potential change.

dialogue.statement: That sounds like a challenging spot to be in, feeling pushed in a direction you weren't entirely sure of from the start. Considering how you ended up here, what do you think your life might look like if you chose to step back and take some time to reflect on what you genuinely want?

I think I'd have a chance to actually breathe and figure things out without all the pressure. I'd probably focus on working for a bit and saving up while I really think about what I want for my future.

Taking a step back to breathe and reflect without the pressure could give you some clarity. If you imagine yourself taking that path, how confident do you feel, on a scale from 0 to 10, about making this change and exploring what truly matters to you?

Honestly, maybe like a 5 or 6? I'm not fully confident because there's still a part of me that's worried about the whole "dropping out" label and if I'm making the right choice. But the idea of taking time to figure things out does sound nice.

You're feeling some uncertainty, though the idea of taking time to explore your path is appealing. The worry about labels and making the right choice is weighing on you. What values or goals do you think are most important to you right now, and how might they influence your decision?

I think what's really important to me is figuring out what makes me happy and what I'm genuinely passionate about, instead of just going through the motions. I want to make sure I'm not rushing into something just because of pressure, and that whatever I choose to do feels right for me.

statement.reasoning: The client has expressed some Change Talk and a tentative confidence level, but there's significant ambivalence with a confidence level of 5 or 6. They are concerned about labels and are unsure about their decision. More exploration of values and goals is needed to strengthen their motivation and resolve ambivalence.

dialogue.statement: Discovering what genuinely makes you happy and ensuring your choices align with your passions and values is vital. Reflecting on this, how do you see these priorities shaping your decision about whether to continue with college or take a different path?

client(guiding): I think these priorities are steering me more towards taking some time off. If I don't do that, I might end up in a degree or career that doesn't really fit me because I rushed into it without considering what I actually want.

However, confidence is not firmly above 6, and ambivalence remains. Further Guiding can build stronger readiness.

dialogue.statement: Allowing yourself that space could indeed lead to a more fulfilling path aligned with your true interests and passions. How does it feel to imagine a future where your choices are driven by what truly excites you rather than external expectations?

client(reflecting): It feels really liberating, honestly. Like a weight would be lifted off my shoulders, and I could focus on things that genuinely make me happy instead of stressing about what others think I should be doing.

statement.reasoning: The client has expressed a clear desire to take time off and explore their path, aligning with their values and goals. dialogue.statement: Imagining a future guided by your true interests sounds freeing. As you consider taking this time off, what steps might you take to ensure you're using this period effectively to explore your passions and relieve that stress?

client(reflecting): I guess I'd start by exploring different job opportunities and maybe taking some classes that interest me, even if they're not for credit, just to see what I like. I might also spend more time on hobbies or projects that I enjoy and see if they spark anything.

Exploring job opportunities and taking classes for interest sound like thoughtful ways to discover your passions. Engaging with hobbies or projects could also reveal what truly excites you. What specific goals or steps do you envision setting for yourself to make the most of this time, and how might you address potential challenges that could arise?

As for challenges, maybe just being mindful of self-doubt and reminding myself that it's okay to take time figuring things out.

How would you like to keep track of your progress during this period, and is there someone you might lean on for support and encouragement?

client(choosing): I'll probably keep a journal or some sort of planner to track what I'm doing and how I'm feeling about it all. As for support, I know my Nana and Dada would be there for me, and maybe even some close friends who understand what I'm going through.

statement.reasoning: The client has outlined a clear action plan of exploring job opportunities and engaging in hobbies, with specific goals for self-exploration and overcoming challenges. They have also identified a support system and a method for self-monitoring. These indicate readiness to advance.

dialogue.statement: Using a journal or planner to track your experiences and feelings is a great way to reflect on your journey. It's wonderful that your Nana, Dada, and close friends are there to support you; having a supportive circle can make a big difference. You've set some solid goals and planned for challenges—with this approach, you're honoring your needs and growth. Remember that this time is about exploring and learning, and it's perfectly normal to take things at your own pace. Looking forward, maybe consider scheduling regular check-ins with yourself or with someone you trust to discuss how things are progressing. You've got this, and I'm really encouraged by the thoughtfulness you're bringing to this decision.
Thanks, I think that could really help keep me on track and stay grounded in what I want. I'll try to remind myself it's okay to go at my own pace.

statement.reasoning: The client has identified steps, coping strategies, and support systems for exploring their interests. They have a concrete plan to track progress, and the session concluded with encouragement and next steps, achieving the closure criteria.

concern:
title: I need advice on dropping out, please help
So my dad just got approved for ssdi, I (18 F) qualify for $900 a month if I'm at least part time enrolled in school. Well, it took my dad a long time to get approved so I thought that once he got approved I could apply to a college and then start getting money pretty quick. Apparently thats not how it works, my dad has to get processed too. Now because no one told me that, (only how he had been accepted after waiting like a year or two already) and I was being pressured to start college for other reasons, I started looking at potential colleges. My grandmother found a pretty nice one and texted me one day to come over to her house and we would look at the school and see how we like it. Well when I got there she already had all the information typed out on the application form for a degree I never wanted in the first place. If it were up to me, I wouldn't have even gone to school in the first place. But it wasn't, I knew how much it meant to my other grandmother (I will be referring to her as Nana). I had already decided that with the "free money" (I say that very lightly lol) and my Nanas eagerness for me to start school, that I would do it, I just wanted to wait a little bit. Well, I thought I had mentioned my unwillingness enough times to stick. I already have a few job offers I could take for the summer this year if I really wanted to. Anyway, I asked my grandmother if I had to do this. She told me I had too. So obviously I thought her and Nana had talked it out and they determined I had to start right away, which was the only reason why I caved in. So I accepted and she called Nana and they paid. When I got home that night, my Nana and Dada (primary caregivers/parental figures) asked me if this is what I wanted. I told them this: "No, but it's something I have to do" referring back to what my grandmother had said previously. Well, here I am a few days later and I just now got off the phone with my Nana who told me she had no idea and that she was never gonna force me to go to college, as well as it would take until the end of the year most likely before I would receive the ssdi benefits and none of which would include money I would have made if I was getting paid as soon as I started school. So now I'm at a crossroads, I never wanted to start school in the first place because I was scared I would give up halfway through or change my mind and switch majors. I wanted to wait and plan everything out and not jump right in. I jumped right into work right after high school and worked myself sick, I didn't wanna repeat that. Tomorrow i think, is the deadline to ask for our money back. I don't wanna be labeled a college dropout. The mere thought of it makes me want to cry tbh. I know that this is mostly my fault for not checking in with both parties. Most of the time they do consult each other about my school so I just assumed they both knew everything. Now I have no idea what to do, I have less than 24 hours to figure out if I drop out and get the money back, or switch majors which will still leave me with the same issue because I have no idea what I want to do. I'm open to hear what literally anyone has to say.

dialogue.statement: Hello! It seems like you might have something on your mind. Whenever you're ready, feel free to share what's been going on with you. I'm here to listen.

Hey, yeah, I've just been thinking a lot about how people might react to me in college, especially with these scars I have. It's just nerve-wracking to think about how people will see me and if they'll judge me based on them.

It's understandable to feel nervous about how others might perceive you, especially when it comes to something so personal. You feel anxious because you're concerned about being judged. What has your experience been with this in the past?

client (exploring): In the past, I've had some pretty mixed reactions. Some people have been understanding, but others have been really judgmental and made me feel like I should hide. It's just tough not knowing what to expect from new people.

Facing mixed reactions in the past can understandably lead to anxiety about new encounters. You feel uncertain because you've experienced both acceptance and judgment. How do these experiences impact how you see yourself or think about interacting with others now?

client (exploring): It's made me second-guess myself a lot and sometimes I just feel really self-conscious, like people are secretly judging me. I want to be open and meet new people in college, but part of me worries about being misunderstood or labeled because of my scars.

statement.reasoning: The client's story, thoughts, and feelings about their scars and concerns about college have been well-explored. Rapport appears to be established, and the client's past experiences and current worries have been clearly articulated. This understanding allows a transition to the Guiding phase to strengthen motivation for change and evoke Change Talk.

dialogue.statement: Entering college with these feelings of self-consciousness is challenging, especially with the desire to connect with others. You're striving for openness and new connections, yet there's a concern about being misunderstood. On a scale of 0-10, how confident do you feel about finding a supportive community in college?

client (reflecting): Maybe around a 4 or 5. I want to believe I'll find a group of people who won't judge me for my past, but the fear of misunderstanding is still pretty strong. It's just hard to shake off the worry.

Recognizing that fear of misunderstanding alongside your hopes for connection is important. A 4 or 5 suggests there's a seed of hope. What might increase your confidence in finding that supportive community in college?

client (reflecting): I think meeting even just one or two people who are accepting could really make a difference. Also, maybe finding a club or group with people who have similar experiences or interest could help me feel more at ease.

Building connections with even a few understanding individuals or joining a group with shared experiences sounds like a meaningful step. It's significant that you've identified these possibilities. What personal values or strengths might help you pursue these connections in college?

client (reflecting): I guess I'm pretty empathetic and open-minded, probably because of what I've been through. I really try to give others the benefit of the doubt and listen without judgment, so maybe that'll help me find the right people.

statement.reasoning: The client has shown some hope and identified strategies for connecting with supportive peers, but confidence remains low at 4-5. Ambivalence persists, as fears of judgment are strong. More guiding is needed to strengthen confidence and resolve ambivalence before developing specific action plans.

dialogue.statement: Your empathy and open-mindedness are powerful strengths that can indeed guide you towards forming meaningful connections. client (reflecting): I think I'll try to approach people with an open heart and just be myself, hoping they'll do the same in return. If I focus on listening and being there for others, maybe it'll encourage them to do the same for me.

statement.reasoning: The client has identified potential steps to find supportive connections and recognizes their empathetic strengths. client (considering): I like the idea of a follow-up session to track how things are going. It could be helpful to talk about what worked and what didn't, and maybe adjust my approach if needed. Plus, it would be nice to share any positives that come out of it too.

Remember, every step forward, no matter how small, is progress. Keep embracing your courage and patience as you move forward.

That sounds like a good plan. I'll keep reminding myself that each step counts and not to rush things. Let's set up that follow-up session to keep me accountable and to have something to look forward to.

concern:
title: How would you react to a classmate with old self harm scars? I’m scared of how people will treat me in college
I’ve finally committed to stopping self harm for good, and I haven’t done it in a long time, but my scars are going to be with me for life, no matter how much they fade. They are clearly self inflicted. It’s going to be pretty difficult for me to hide them at all times, especially if I end up living in on-campus housing. What would you do if you had a classmate or roommate with old scars like mine? I’m afraid that I’ll attract people who think I’m an easy target or that people will avoid talking to me if they know that I used to self harm. I’ve gotten a lot of negative and extreme reactions to my scars over the years. Some people have made it very clear to me that they think wearing short sleeves is selfish and that I should simply face the consequences of my actions and cover up no matter what in order to spare people the “horror and shock of seeing my arms”. To what extent do you agree with them? Should I just get sleeve tattoos and skin grafts in order to avoid all this mess as soon as I turn 18? Would you be uncomfortable around someone who looks like me? Would you think that I’m a freak or that I’m crazy?

dialogue.statement: Hello! I'm here to listen and support you. What's on your mind today?

Hey, thanks for meeting with me. I've just been feeling really anxious about my choice of major and the possibility of transferring schools. It's like I'm worried I won't make the right decision in time.

title: I feel like I screwed myself over freshman year and now I’m panicking.

So going into college I was dead set on majoring in political science. I liked it in college, I want to go into law, it seemed natural. But the more I researched and took classes I didn’t feel like it was worth it. There didn’t seem to be a lot of job security with higher pay like I was looking for, and so I wanted to switch. I really enjoyed my geology classes and it seemed like that was the route to take. But I have always wanted to double major and never even considered just majoring in one thing. So I was going to do polisci and geology.


But still, even after last semester, polisci just didn’t give me good feelings. I took a business class and I loved it. It was difficult but I felt like it was a fun kind of difficult that I felt proud of myself for figuring out over time. I then started thinking, would it be bad if I majored in geology and something business related? I was also looking into computer science as I love computers and such but might be going in over my head. I feel like it’s late in the game and I’m planning on transferring so I don’t want to have to restart as a freshman. 



Is it too late to do this? My biggest concern is transferring, as I really don’t know if switching now would be an option. I’m a sophomore planning on transferring in the fall, but this is making me sick to my stomach.

Yeah, I guess it's that I find chemistry interesting and it's kind of what I thought I should do, but English and writing really excite me and feel more natural. It's like I enjoy the idea of creating stories and working with words so much more.

Your passion for English and writing seems to bring you a lot of excitement and joy, which is quite different from how you feel about chemistry. What do you think it is about creating stories and working with words that feels so natural to you?

I think it's the freedom and creativity that come with writing. I love being able to express ideas and emotions through stories, and it feels like a way for me to connect with others on a deeper level. It just feels right, you know?

concern:
title: Should I room alone as a freshman?
I’m starting college in the fall and have the opportunity to have a single room. If it weren’t for the social aspect, I would immediately go for it. However, since I’m going to be at a completely new school, I’m wondering if I should get a roommate instead to avoid becoming friend-less. I really like being social, but initiating friendships on my own can be hard for me. I can’t tell what the best option is and am wondering what I should do

dialogue.statement: Hello! It's nice to meet you. What's on your mind today?
Hey, thanks for seeing me. I've been really stressed about this honors program I'm in, and I'm thinking about quitting it. It's just been a lot to handle.
Balancing a demanding program can certainly feel overwhelming. Can you share more about what's been particularly stressful for you?

Well, I feel like I've been all over the place trying to keep up with deadlines, especially with this big project coming up. Plus, dealing with personal stuff hasn't made it any easier. It's just been hard to manage everything at once.
Juggling deadlines alongside personal challenges can truly feel like a lot to manage. Could you tell me more about how these responsibilities and personal matters are impacting you day-to-day?

client(exploring): Honestly, it's been affecting my sleep and focus a lot. I just feel this constant pressure, and it's making my anxiety worse. Some days it's tough just to get through my regular classes, let alone the extra program stuff.

statement.reasoning: The client has shared their concerns, feelings, and the impact on their day-to-day life, providing a comprehensive view of their stressors. The therapist has demonstrated empathy and understanding, indicating a solid rapport. The session has not become repetitive and has effectively covered the client's context, emotions, and thoughts.

client(guiding): If the pressure eased up, I think I'd feel more at peace and able to enjoy my classes more. I might actually have time to focus on things I care about outside of school too, without feeling guilty or stressed.
Imagining that sense of peace and being able to focus on things you love sounds really appealing. How does that vision align with your longer-term goals or what you value most in your life?

Honestly, that vision aligns pretty well with what I value. I want to enjoy my time in college and learn the things I'm passionate about without burning out. Long term, I just want to make choices that help me feel balanced and content, rather than constantly stressed and anxious.

It seems like finding a balance between pursuing your passions and maintaining your well-being is really important to you. What might be some small steps you could consider now that align with those values of balance and contentment?

Maybe I could start with setting more realistic goals for myself, like breaking down tasks into smaller, manageable pieces. I guess I should also try to set aside some time for things I enjoy or practices that help me relax, like meditation or spending time with friends. I’m thinking of talking to my advisor again, but this time really explaining how this is affecting me.

dialogue.statement: Creating manageable goals and setting aside time for relaxation can be valuable steps towards that balance you're seeking. client(choosing): I think starting with a weekly schedule that balances study and relaxation time could really help. I want to have a better idea of how much time I need for everything, and hopefully it’ll reduce my stress. Talking to my advisor about possibly adjusting deadlines also sounds good, but it makes me a bit nervous.

concern:
title: Quitting a Program
Hello,

I just wanted other perspectives on a matter: I am in an honors program at my school, that I no longer think is fit for me. I can leave it but my advisor thinks I should stay so that I stand out. I don’t usually quit things but my anxiety is so high.

I have a project that’s due for the program very soon. I have terribly managed my time regarding it, while dealing with personal issues throughout the semester on top of my other course assignments. I’m thinking about just not turning anything in  and leaving regardless of what others want me to do but I’m scared.

What would you guys do?

p.s. This is NOT me quitting school, just the program.

p.p.s. I am diagnosed with general anxiety disorder, which has been causing me some personal issues.

dialogue.statement: Hi there! How are you feeling today? What's been on your mind lately?

Hey! I've been okay, just daydreaming a bit about different paths I could've taken in school. It's interesting to think about what might've been if I chose a different major, like Microbiology or Marine Biology.
It sounds like you're reflecting on your past choices and imagining different possibilities. What draws you to think about those particular fields now?

I guess it's the curiosity about the unknown and the idea of exploring new worlds, whether it's on a microscopic level or underwater. Plus, I’ve always loved science and nature documentaries, so those fields seem really fascinating to me.

Your love for science and nature really shines through, and it sounds like that curiosity and fascination with the unknown are important to you. How do these reflections make you feel about your current path?
They make me feel a bit wistful, like I'm missing out on something exciting. But at the same time, I'm still pretty invested in what I'm doing with marketing and thinking about law school.

statement.reasoning: The client has shared their thoughts, feelings, and relevant context about their reflections on past choices and current path. There's a clear understanding and empathy established, and mutually agreed goals are emerging. The conversation can now focus on exploring motivations for change.

dialogue.statement: It's interesting to hear how you balance your passion for science with your current path. What do you think it might be like if you explored this curiosity further alongside your current pursuits?

I think it could be really fulfilling, like having the best of both worlds. Maybe I could find a way to incorporate my love for science into marketing or law, like focusing on environmental law or working in a science-focused marketing firm.
Exploring these possibilities sounds energizing for you. What would it mean for you to integrate your passion for science into your career path?

client(guiding): It would mean a lot, like I wouldn’t have to choose between my interests. I could see myself really thriving in a role that bridges my marketing or law skills with my love for science, like advocating for environmental causes or promoting scientific innovations.

Bridging your interests seems like a powerful way to enrich your career and personal fulfillment. How confident do you feel, on a scale from 0 to 10, about taking some steps to explore these integrated career paths further?
I'd say I'm around a 7. I'm pretty confident because I know there are ways to combine my interests, but there's always that bit of uncertainty about how exactly to do it and if it's the right move.

statement.reasoning: The client has expressed Change Talk by discussing how integrating science into their career could be fulfilling and has a specific goal of exploring integrated career paths. The client's confidence level is 7, indicating readiness for planning. Ambivalence is reduced, with excitement about combining interests evident.

dialogue.statement: Your confidence level of 7 shows a strong belief in your ability to find a path that combines your interests. Considering your interests in environmental law and science-focused marketing, which option would you feel ready to explore first? For example, you might consider researching specific roles or connecting with professionals in those fields. How does that sound as a starting point?

client(choosing): That sounds like a good plan. I think starting with researching roles in environmental law could be really interesting. I've always wanted to understand more about how law interacts with environmental issues, and talking to people in the field might give me a clearer picture of what it entails.

Researching roles in environmental law sounds like a solid starting step. As you explore this path, what resources or strategies do you think would be helpful in learning more about the field and connecting with professionals?

I think online resources like articles and webinars would be a good start, and maybe joining some relevant groups on LinkedIn to network with people in the field. I could also reach out to professors or alumni who might have insights or connections.

Those sound like excellent strategies for gaining more insight and building connections in the field. As you consider these steps, what might be some potential challenges, and how could you address them? For instance, if reaching out to professionals feels daunting, we could explore ways to make that process easier.

client(considering): Yeah, reaching out to professionals can be a bit intimidating since I don't want to come off as just using them for info. Maybe I could start by asking professors for introductions or advice on how to approach these conversations, so it feels more genuine and less awkward.

statement.reasoning: The client has identified a clear goal of exploring environmental law and has formulated a concrete action plan involving research and networking. They have discussed potential barriers like intimidation in networking and agreed on strategies to address them. The client demonstrates commitment and confidence, meeting the readiness signals for moving forward.

dialogue.statement:
That sounds like a thoughtful approach, starting with professors who can offer guidance and perhaps ease you into those professional conversations. It's natural to feel a bit apprehensive, and reaching out through familiar connections can certainly help make it more comfortable. As you move forward with this plan, remember to be gentle with yourself and acknowledge the courage it takes to pursue these new paths.

concern:
title: Torn between getting a business, psychology, or creative computing degree
If you've taken any of these 3 courses before, what advice would you give someone who is choosing between them?

I'm in Creative Computing right now but I have the option to transfer while its still early.
I chose it because it seems like the course that has the most potential for a good job in the future, considering where the world is headed.

However, I find maths and coding a bit challenging. It was our first coding class today and I already felt left behind. Some of my classmates already studied the basics before they went into uni so I felt really dumb.
I know I can learn it as I go along but it just feels really daunting. Like can I really do this for my whole life? 

I used to be interested in taking Psychology or Business but after seeing all the advice online from people who have Psychology and Business degrees... they mostly say that they're "useless" unless you do a Masters or be good at networking. 

Part of me wants to take on the challenge of doing a more difficult degree while another part of me wants to go the more comfortable route. I'm a pretty sociable person and I'm good at writing essays and being creative, that's why I chose creative computing because I thought it would be more creative but the coding part is what I find difficult.

... what do you think?

dialogue.statement: Hello! How are you feeling today? What's on your mind?

concern:
title: Graduating soon and worried about repaying loans. Any advice?
I am absolutely terrified to graduate simply because of only having six months to find a job and establish myself before starting repayment. I know federal loans can be based on income, but I also have a huge private loan because of an error with my university’s financial aid office ($30k). I’m going to be graduating with a not so useful environmental biology/zoology degree. The reason why I felt secure in this degree is because I absolutely do plan to go for my Master’s, but I’d really like to take a yearlong break. On top of this, I plan to move out of state (permanently) to attend school for my Master’s since there’s a ton of universities in the state with great programs, and also because this state has way more job opportunities for my degree. A ton more than my home state. 

I’m in my early 20s and I feel like I should have learned how to be an adult by now but I feel everything I’m talking about and my expectations for my future may be immature and naive. Reality is probably going to hit me like a truck.
